revision.comment: /* Origin */ Ian Stewart is primarily a mathematician, not a scientist
revision.text:
A '''lie-to-children''' (plural '''lies-to-children''') is a simplified explanation of technical or complex subjects as a teaching method for children and [[Layperson|laypeople]]. The technique has been incorporated by academics within the fields of [[biology]], [[evolution]], [[bioinformatics]] and the [[social sciences]]. It is closely related to the philosophical concept known as [[Wittgenstein's ladder]]. == Origin == {{multiple image |title=''The Science of Discworld'' authors |total_width=400 |width1=1382|height1= 1709|image1=10.12.12TerryPratchettByLuigiNovi1.jpg|caption1=[[Terry Pratchett]]|alt1=Bearded man with hat and leather jacket |width2=784|height2=866|image2=Ian stewart mathematician.jpg|caption2=[[Ian Stewart (mathematician)|Ian Stewart]]|alt2=White-haired man in blue shirt |footer=Two of the three authors of ''[[The Science of Discworld]]'' |caption_align=center }} The "lie-to-children" concept was first discussed by scientist [[Jack Cohen (scientist)|Jack Cohen]] and mathematician [[Ian Stewart (mathematician)|Ian Stewart]] in the 1994 book ''[[The Collapse of Chaos]]: Discovering Simplicity in a Complex World''.{{cite book | title = [[The Collapse of Chaos]]: Discovering Simplicity in a Complex World|first2=Ian |last2=Stewart|author-link2=Ian Stewart (mathematician)|first1=Jack|last1=Cohen|authorlink1=Jack Cohen (scientist)|publisher=[[Penguin Books]]|year=1994|isbn=978-0-670-84983-3|pages=7–9}} They further elaborated upon their views in their coauthored 1997 book ''[[Figments of Reality]]: The Evolution of the Curious Mind''.{{cite book|first=Andrew|last=Sawyer|chapter=Narrativium and Lies-to-Children: 'Palatable Instruction in 'The Science of Discworld'|authorlink=Andrew Sawyer|pages=80–82|editor1-first=Andrew M.|editor1-last=Butler|title=An Unofficial Companion to the Novels of Terry Pratchett|year=2007|publisher=Greenwood|isbn=978-1-84645-043-3}}{{cite book | title = [[Figments of Reality]]: The Evolution of the Curious Mind|first1=Ian |last1=Stewart|author-link1=Ian Stewart (mathematician)|first2=Jack|last2=Cohen|authorlink2=Jack Cohen (scientist)|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|year=1997|isbn=978-0-521-57155-5|pages=37–38; 140}} The concept gained greater exposure when they collaborated with popular author [[Terry Pratchett]], discussing "lies-to-children" in the book ''[[The Science of Discworld]]'' (1999).{{cite book | title = [[The Science of Discworld]] | first1 = Terry | last1 = Pratchett | author-link1 = Terry Pratchett | first2 = Ian|last2=Stewart|author-link2=Ian Stewart (mathematician)|first3=Jack|last3=Cohen | author-link3=Jack Cohen (scientist)|isbn =978-0-8041-6894-6|year=2014 |pages=28–30|publisher=Anchor; 2014 Reprint Edition of 1999 book; Paperback}} Cohen and Stewart discussed "lies-to-children" and the desire inherent in society for a view of simplicity with regards to complex concepts in their 1994 book ''The Collapse of Chaos''.{{cite news|accessdate=27 February 2016|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-670-84983-3|title=Nonfiction Book Review: The Collapse of Chaos|work=[[Publishers Weekly]]|date=April 1994|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160227032441/http://www.publishersweekly.com/978-0-670-84983-3|archivedate=27 February 2016}} Stewart and Cohen wrote in ''Figments of Reality'' (1997) that the lie-to-children concept reflected the difficulty inherent in reducing complex concepts during the education process.{{cite news|first=Douglas|last=Chapman|title=Book Review – Figments of Reality: The Evolution of the Curious Mind|work=Strange Magazine|year=1997|accessdate=28 February 2016|url=http://www.strangemag.com/reviews/figmentsofreality.html|archivedate=19 September 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919014619/http://www.strangemag.com/reviews/figmentsofreality.html}} Stewart and Cohen noted reality itself was viewed within the prism of human perspective: "Any description suitable for human minds to grasp must be ''some'' type of lie-to-children — real reality is always much too complicated for our limited minds." Librarian and editor [[Andrew Sawyer]] discussed the "lie-to-children" concept introduced by scientists Cohen and Stewart in their early two non-fiction books. Sawyer wrote: "In ''The Collapse of Chaos'' and ''Figments of Reality'', we also come across the concept of 'lies-to-children' — the necessarily simplified stories we tell children and students as a foundation for understanding so that eventually they can discover that they are not, in fact, ''true''." The definition given in ''The Science of Discworld'' (1999) is as follows: "A lie-to-children is a statement that is false, but which nevertheless leads the child's mind towards a more accurate explanation, one that the child will only be able to appreciate if it has been primed with the lie".{{cite journal|first1=Kirsten|last1=Walsh|first2=Adrian|last2=Currie|title=Caricatures, Myths, and White Lies|journal=[[Metaphilosophy (journal)|Metaphilosophy]] |volume=46|issue=3|date=22 July 2015|pages=414–435|doi=10.1111/meta.12139|issn=1467-9973}}{{cite journal|first=Don|last=Fallis|title=What Is Disinformation?|journal=[[Library Trends]]|volume=63|issue=3|year=2015|pages=401–426|doi=10.1353/lib.2015.0014|issn=0024-2594}} The authors acknowledge that some people might dispute the applicability of the term ''lie'', while defending it on the grounds that "it is for the best possible reasons, but it is still a lie". This viewpoint is derived from earlier perspectives within the field of [[philosophy of science]].{{cite book|first=Anthony|last=Judge|accessdate=28 February 2016|url=https://www.laetusinpraesens.org/docs00s/mislead.php|chapter=Strategic leadership as essentially a "shell game" with potential opponents, followers and dissidents?|title=Emergence of a Global Misleadership Council – misleading as vital to governance of the future?|date=1 July 2007|archivedate=31 October 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121031134328/http://www.laetusinpraesens.org/docs00s/mislead.php|publisher=Laetus in Praesens}} In a 1999 interview, Pratchett commented upon the phrase: "I ''like'' the lies-to-children motif, because it underlies the way we run our society and resonates nicely with Discworld." He was critical of problems inherent in early education: "You arrive with your sparkling A-levels all agleam, and the first job of the tutors is to reveal that what you thought was true is only true for a given value of 'truth'." Pratchett cautioned: "Most of us need just 'enough' knowledge of the sciences, and it's delivered to us in metaphors and analogies that bite us in the bum if we think they're the same as the truth." Cohen and Stewart further elaborated upon the lie-to-children trope in a 2002 book they coauthored on [[exobiology]], ''[[Evolving the Alien]]: The Science of Extraterrestrial Life''.{{cite news|first=David|last=Langford|authorlink=David Langford|work=[[New Scientist]]|title=Evolving the Alien: The science of extraterrestrial life by Jack Cohen and Ian Stewart|date=5 October 2002|accessdate=28 February 2016|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg17623636-300-evolving-the-alien-the-science-of-extraterrestrial-life-by-jack-cohen-and-ian-stewart/|subscription=yes|archivedate=28 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160228172211/https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg17623636-300-evolving-the-alien-the-science-of-extraterrestrial-life-by-jack-cohen-and-ian-stewart/|issn=0262-4079}} Within the work, the authors were critical of use of lie-to-children as an educational methodology which had an unfortunate side-effect of reducing complex science concepts to overly simplified explanations. Stewart was asked in a 2015 interview about his views on Pratchett beyond the influence of lie-to-children, and the author's take on the understanding of science. Stewart commented upon the interaction between himself and Cohen with Pratchett during the writing process: "Terry wasn't trained as a scientist, but he had the right kind of critical attitude. He was extraordinarily widely read, and would ask all sorts of unexpected questions that really got me and Jack thinking."{{cite news|accessdate=28 February 2016|work=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/live/2015/jun/05/ian-stewart-on-the-science-of-terry-pratchetts-discworld-webchat|title=Ian Stewart on the science of Terry Pratchett's Discworld – as it happened|first=Sam|last=Jordison|date=9 June 2015|archivedate=29 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151229081705/http://www.theguardian.com/books/live/2015/jun/05/ian-stewart-on-the-science-of-terry-pratchetts-discworld-webchat}} Authors Michael Moorhouse and Paul Barry recommended the original works discussing the concept for further analysis of the phenomenon: "These are well worth a read if you fancy a laugh while pretending to work." == Use in adult education == The term "lie to children" should not be taken to imply that it is exclusively used in childhood education. Educators in secondary and post-secondary schools employ increasingly-accurate yet still "untrue" models as a means of explicating complex topics. A typical example of this is found in physics, where the [[Bohr model]] of atomic electron shells is still often used to introduce atomic structure before moving on to [[Bohr model#Refinements|more complex models]] based on [[matrix mechanics]]; and in chemistry, where the [[Acid-base reaction#Arrhenius definition |Arrhenius definitions of acids and bases]] are often introduced, followed (in a manner similar to the historical development of the model) by the [[Brønsted–Lowry acid–base theory |Brønsted–Lowry]] definitions and then the [[Lewis acids and bases |Lewis]] definitions. High school teachers and university instructors often explain at the outset that the model they are about to present is incomplete. An example of this is given by [[Gerald Sussman]] during the 1986 video recording of the [[Hal Abelson |Abelson]]-Sussman Lectures ([https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-001-structure-and-interpretation-of-computer-programs-spring-2005/video-lectures/1b-procedures-and-processes-substitution-model/ lecture 1-b]):
If we're going to understand processes and how we control them, then we have to have a mapping from the mechanisms of this procedure into the way in which these processes behave. What we're going to have is a formal, or semi-formal, mechanical model whereby you understand how a machine could, in fact, in principle, do this. Whether or not the actual machine really does what I'm about to tell you is completely irrelevant at this moment. In fact, this is an [[Function model|engineering model]], in the same way that, [for an] electrical resistor, we write down a model V = IR — it's approximately true, but it's not really true; if I put enough current through the resistor, it goes boom, so the voltage is not always proportional to the current, but for some purposes the model is appropriate. In particular, the model we're going to describe right now, which I call the substitution model, is the simplest model that we have for understanding how procedures work and how processes work — how procedures yield processes. And that substitution model will be accurate for most of the things we'll be dealing with in the next few days. But eventually, it will become impossible to sustain the illusion that that's the way the machine works, and we'll go to other, more specific and particular models that will show more detail.
== Analysis == [[File:DavidLangford.01.jpg|thumb|British author [[David Langford]] wrote in 1999 that his favorite theme within ''Discworld'' was the lie-to-children trope.{{cite book|first=David|last=Langford|pages=38–40|title=CROSSTALK: Interviews Conducted by David Langford|year=2015|publisher=Lulu.com; Republished from: Amazon.co.uk, 1999|isbn=978-1-326-29982-8|authorlink=David Langford|chapter=Terry Pratchett, Jack Cohen and Ian Stewart: 1999}}{{cite news|date=1999|title=Weird Science|work=Amazon.co.uk|first=David|last=Langford|authorlink=David Langford|url=http://www.lspace.org/about-terry/interviews/amazon.html|accessdate=28 February 2016|archivedate=28 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160228165648/http://www.lspace.org/about-terry/interviews/amazon.html|publisher=The L-Space Web: Interviews – Interview Conducted by Amazon.co.uk with Terry Pratchett, Ian Stewart and Jack Cohen}}]] The concept of lie-to-children was discussed at-length in 2000 by [[Andrew Sawyer]], where the subject itself was included in the article title: "Narrativium and Lies-to-Children: 'Palatable Instruction in 'The Science of Discworld'".{{cite journal|first=Andy|last=Sawyer|journal=Hungarian Journal of English and American Studies (HJEAS)|volume=6|issue=1|year=2000|pages=155–178|publisher=Centre for Arts, Humanities and Sciences (CAHS), acting on behalf of the University of Debrecen CAHS|jstor=41274079|subscription=yes|title=Narrativium and Lies-to-Children: 'Palatable Instruction in 'The Science of Discworld'|issn=1218-7364|authorlink=Andrew Sawyer}} Sawyer wrote that: "The 'lies-to-children' we tell ourselves about science are a different form of science fiction: one, perhaps where 'fiction' qualifies the word 'science.' They are 'fictions about science' rather than 'science fictions.'" Sawyer concluded: "The strength of ''The Science of Discworld'' — and why in many ways it is something new in science writing — derives from Pratchett's story being more than a parable constructed for the specific purpose of explaining what the scientists have to say. It is, as has been said, a commentary/parody of the scientific method". In a contribution about [[evolution]] for the 2001 book ''Nonlinear Dynamics in the Life and Social Sciences'', [[Reproductive biology|reproductive biologist]] [[Jack Cohen (scientist)|Jack Cohen]] discussed the lie-to-children teaching technique and its use educating students on the concept of evolution and its complex facets including the notion that [[DNA]] is an architectural guide for life. The author concluded: "Only the search for universal features, while treasuring all the exceptional specifics, offers some hope of sketching out the general shape of the evolutionary process so that we can explain it honestly as a Lie-to-Children."{{cite book|first=Jack|last=Cohen|authorlink=Jack Cohen (scientist)|chapter=Complexity of Evolution|pages=357–359|editor1-first=William H. |editor1-last=Sulis|editor2-first= Irina Nikolaevna |editor2-last=Trofimova|title=Nonlinear Dynamics in the Life and Social Sciences|year=2001|series=NATO Science, Series A: Life Sciences, Vol. 320|publisher=IOS|isbn=978-1-58603-020-9}} D.J. Jeffrey and Robert M. Corless of the Ontario Research Centre for Computer Algebra at the [[University of Western Ontario]] wrote in their 2001 [[computer science]] paper on [[linear algebra]] instruction on the teaching concept. Jeffrey and Corless identified a "useful" lie-to-children, as one in which: "The pedagogical point is to avoid unnecessary burdens on the student’s first encounter with the concept." The authors gave an example from early childhood mathematics instruction: "We happily teach children that 'you cannot take 3 from 2' because we are confident that someone will later introduce them to negative numbers."{{cite journal|first1=D.J.|last1=Jeffrey|first2=Robert M.|last2=Corless|publisher=Ontario Research Centre for Computer Algebra at the [[University of Western Ontario]]|title=Teaching Linear Algebra with and to Computers|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160227024502/http://epatcm.any2any.us/10thAnniversaryCD/EP/2001/ATCMP127/fullpaper.pdf|archivedate=27 February 2016|accessdate=27 February 2016|date=2001|url=http://epatcm.any2any.us/10thAnniversaryCD/EP/2001/ATCMP127/fullpaper.pdf}} Corless further expounded on this view in a subsequent paper published in 2004, writing: "A 'lie to children' is a useful oversimplification that starts one on the path to better knowledge. It is a truth unacknowledged that mathematics before computers was a lie to children."{{cite journal|first=Robert M.|last=Corless|url=http://kong.apmaths.uwo.ca/~rcorless/frames/PAPERS/EDUC/CMTpaper.pdf|accessdate=27 February 2016|date=July 2004|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160227025107/http://kong.apmaths.uwo.ca/~rcorless/frames/PAPERS/EDUC/CMTpaper.pdf|archivedate=27 February 2016|title=Computer-Mediated Thinking|publisher=ORCCA and the Department of Applied Mathematics at the [[University of Western Ontario]]}} In their 2004 book ''Bioinformatics, Biocomputing and Perl'', authors Michael Moorhouse and Paul Barry explained how the lie-to-children model may be utilized as a teaching technique for the concepts of [[protein]], [[RNA]], and DNA. Moorhouse and Barry wrote that the lie-to-children methodology can reduce complex academic notions to a simpler format for basic understanding. The authors conclude that the lie-to-children teaching technique: "allows the basic features to be understood without confusing things by considering exceptions and enhancements."{{cite book|first1=Michael|last1=Moorhouse|first2=Paul|last2=Barry|year=2004|pages=4–6|title=Bioinformatics Biocomputing and Perl: An Introduction to Bioinformatics Computing Skills and Practice|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-0-470-85331-3}} Haroom Kharem and Genevieve Collura were critical of the teaching practice, in a contribution to the 2010 book ''Teaching Bilingual/Bicultural Children''.{{cite book|year=2010|title=Teaching Bilingual/Bicultural Children: Teachers Talk about Language and Learning |chapter=Chapter Seventeen: Teachers Rethinking Their Pedagogical Attitudes in the Bicultural/Bilingual Classroom|pages=152–155|first1=Haroom|last1=Kharem|first2=Genevieve|last2=Collura|editor1-first=Lourdes Diaz|editor1-last= Soto|editor2-first=Haroon|editor2-last=Kharem|series=Counterpoints (Book 371)|publisher=Peter Lang Publishing|isbn=978-1-4331-0718-4|jstor=42980693|subscription=yes}} The authors wrote that using this teaching method was a form of disrespect for the truth. Kharem and Collura lament that rather than imparting truth to children, "a pedagogy of stupidification is promoted in which teachers imbue students with untruths and then wonder why education has problems. Sooner or later the fabrications we teach students will come to light and the respect educators expect from students will become disingenuous." [[North Eastern Hill University]] [[economics]] professor Sudhanshu K. Mishra in 2010 defined the phrase as: "A lie-to-children is a lie, often a platitude, which may use euphemism(s), which is told to make an adult subject acceptable to children." Mishra gave as an example parents who engage in mythology by lying to their children and telling them they were [[Stork#Storks and childbirth|brought by a stork to the house]], instead of explaining [[childbirth]].{{cite journal|first=Sudhanshu K. |last=Mishra|accessdate=28 February 2016|title=An Essay on the Nature and Significance of Deception and Telling Lies|url=https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/22906/1/|date=23 May 2010|archivedate=28 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160228033645/https://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/22906/1/|journal=Munich Personal RePEc Archive; MPRA Paper No. 22906}} In a 2011 contribution to the academic journal ''Digital Difference'', Hamish Macleod and Jen Ross discussed the lie-to-children concept and wrote that this teaching methodology can have the negative impact of introducing studying difficulties to students as they progress further in their education. They cautioned this could lead to a negative influence on students' future behaviors. Macleod and Ross wrote: "Playing devil's advocate is in itself a challenging notion for many learners, who may, especially in their early years of higher education, be conditioned by what Stewart and Cohen call 'lies to children' to expect simple and unambiguous questions and equally simple answers."{{cite journal|first1=Hamish|last1=Macleod|first2=Jenn|last2=Ross|title=Structure, Authority and Other Noncepts: Teaching in Fool-ish Spaces|journal=Digital Difference: Perspectives on Online Learning.|year=2011|publisher=Sense Publishers|pages=15–28|accessdate=28 February 2016|url=http://www.research.ed.ac.uk/portal/files/13447040/Structure_Authority_and_Other_Noncepts.pdf|archivedate=28 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160228173510/http://www.research.ed.ac.uk/portal/files/13447040/Structure_Authority_and_Other_Noncepts.pdf|doi=10.1007/978-94-6091-580-2_2|isbn=978-94-6091-580-2}} {{quote box |width=25em | bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=right |halig=left | salign=right|quote="Lies-to-children are not strictly true, but they’re simplified in a way that makes them easier to grasp".|source= —[[Chad Orzel]], ''[[Forbes]]''}} Writing in 2011 for the [[Carleton College]] website, [[geophysicist]] Kim Kastens in a column with her daughter at first found the notion of lie-to-children as surprising.{{cite news|accessdate=26 February 2016|url=http://serc.carleton.edu/earthandmind/posts/lies_children.html|title=Telling Lies to Children|date=26 October 2011|first1=Kim |last1=Kastens|first2= Dana |last2=Chayes |work=Earth and Mind|archivedate=5 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205090900/http://serc.carleton.edu/earthandmind/posts/lies_children.html|publisher=[[Carleton College]]}} Kastens delved further into the issue, and identified specific instances where a lie-to-children teaching technique would do more harm than good for students. The worst examples included a lie-to-children which would later have to be unlearned following teaching from subsequent professors, an instance where the student is successfully able to identify the factual inaccuracy and knows more about it than the teacher, and using the technique without having a "master plan" involving progressive learning. In her 2011 book ''The Children's Bill of Emotional Rights'', Eileen Johnson discussed the lies told by parents to their children during the formation of childhood fictional mythology and pointed out the inherent problems this could raise in the future during the parenting process. Johnson cautioned: "Why do we tell these lies to children? At some point we have to admit we were lying. Parents are not sure how much of this deceit is right, how far to go with it, and how and when to explain it was all a lie."{{cite book|pages=38–40|title=The Children's Bill of Emotional Rights: A Guide to the Needs of Children|year=2011|first=Eileen|last=Johnson|publisher=Jason Aronson, Inc.|isbn=978-0-7657-0850-2}} Kirsten Walsh and Adrian Currie contributed a 2015 article to the journal ''[[Metaphilosophy (journal)|Metaphilosophy]]'' in which they quoted the verbatim definition of lie-to-children from ''The Science of Discworld'' and discussed the impact of such behavior on students. Walsh and Currie concluded that mythmaking within education in order to teach a more complex concept is a form of unwarranted behavior with detrimental impact upon instruction methodology. In a 2015 article, ''[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]]'' compared the concept to [[Wittgenstein's ladder]], and defined it: "that in order to get across a complicated idea, sometimes you need to use an explanation that is actually wrong but which helps a child – or anyone learning about anything complex – build an understanding of that issue."{{cite news | url=http://theconversation.com/netanyahus-narrative-how-the-israeli-pm-is-rewriting-history-to-suit-himself-49759 | title=Netanyahu’s narrative: how the Israeli PM is rewriting history to suit himself | work=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] | date=27 October 2015 | accessdate=4 February 2016|archivedate=28 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151028131940/http://theconversation.com/netanyahus-narrative-how-the-israeli-pm-is-rewriting-history-to-suit-himself-49759}} Writing for ''[[Forbes]]'' in 2015, [[physics]] [[professor]] and [[science journalist]] [[Chad Orzel]] explained the concept: "Lies-to-children are not strictly true, but they’re simplified in a way that makes them easier to grasp for children, and provide a framework that allows for future elaboration."{{cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chadorzel/2015/11/03/the-scientific-method-is-a-myth-long-live-the-scientific-method|accessdate=26 February 2016|work=[[Forbes]]|title='The Scientific Method' Is A Myth, Long Live The Scientific Method|first=Chad|last=Orzel|authorlink=Chad Orzel|date=3 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151112005555/http://www.forbes.com/sites/chadorzel/2015/11/03/the-scientific-method-is-a-myth-long-live-the-scientific-method/|archivedate=12 November 2015}} Orzel praised the [[University of California Museum of Paleontology]] initiative ''Understanding Science'' for its strategy of going beyond a simple explanation of the [[scientific method]] in a lie-to-children format, and instead going into more depth and specifics to directly inform others on how science impacts their daily quality of living. British writer [[Tim Worstall]] expounded upon the lie-to-children phenomenon in education, in a 2015 article for ''Forbes''. He wrote: "that’s what Terry Pratchett pointed out education was: lies to children to help them make some sense of the world. When they become older, more capable of nuance, then we point this out to them: those previous stories were gross simplifications and now you need to know the caveats." Worstall stressed that this form of educational methodology was ubiquitous across multiple academic disciplines: "This is true of any form of education by the way. We don’t start music classes with atonality, we start with simple scales. We don’t do syncopation until we’ve mastered 2/4 and 4/4. Einstein’s corrections at the margin to Newton come quite late in a physics education."{{cite news|first=Tim|last=Worstall|authorlink=Tim Worstall|accessdate=28 February 2016|work=[[Forbes]]|title=To Prove Econ 101 Is Wrong You Do Need To Understand Econ 101|date=25 November 2015|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2015/11/25/to-prove-econ-101-is-wrong-you-do-need-to-understand-econ-101|archivedate=11 February 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160211163351/http://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2015/11/25/to-prove-econ-101-is-wrong-you-do-need-to-understand-econ-101/}} == See also == {{Linguistics}} A '''linguist''' in the academic sense is a person who studies [[natural language]] (an academic discipline known as [[linguistics]]). Ambiguously, the word is sometimes also used to refer to a [[Polyglot (person)|polyglot]] (one who knows several languages), or a grammarian (a scholar of [[grammar]]), but these two uses of the word are distinct (and one does not have to be a polyglot in order to be an academic linguist).<ref>The word ''linguistician'' has been coined to refer to one who studies linguistics, in order to avoid this ambiguity, although this word is vanishingly rare and has no currency in the field [http://www.linguistlist.org/issues/5/5-1147.html].</ref> The following is a list of linguists in the academic sense.

[[File:Loipa Araujo agosto2009.jpg|thumbnail|Loipa Araújo]] '''Loipa Araújo''' (born May 27, 1941) is a Cuban [[ballet dancer]], [[ballet master]], and teacher of [[ballet]]. Along with [[Aurora Bosch]], [[Josefina Méndez]], and [[Mirta Plá]], she is regarded as one of the "four jewels of Cuban ballet".<ref name=balletcuba.cult.cu>{{cite web|title=Las cuatro joyas del ballet cubano|url=http://www.balletcuba.cult.cu/cuatro-joyas-del-ballet-cubano/|publisher=Ballet Nacional de Cuba|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> Nicknamed the "Cuban muse of [[Marseilles]]",<ref name=granma.cu>{{cite news|title=France honors Loipa Araújo|url=http://granma.cu/ingles/culture-i/21ener-Loipa.html|newspaper=[[Granma International]]|date=January 21, 2011|accessdate=28 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140304095135/http://granma.cu/ingles/culture-i/21ener-Loipa.html|archivedate=4 March 2014|df=}}</ref> Araújo is considered to be "one of the best ballet teachers in the world today".<ref name="Rodríguez2013">{{cite news|last=Rodríguez de la Sierra|first=Luis|title=Fernando Alonso: Dancer, teacher and co-founder of the Cuban National Ballet|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/fernando-alonso-dancer-teacher-and-cofounder-of-the-cuban-national-ballet-8747278.html|accessdate=28 February 2014|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=August 6, 2013}}</ref> She was a principal artist with the [[Cuban National Ballet]] (''Ballet Nacional de Cuba''; BNC).
==Early years== Born in [[Havana]] in 1941, Araújo's father was a [[psychiatrist]].<ref name=danceuk.org2011>{{cite web|title=Loipa Araújo, leading cuban ballerina discusses parallels between dance and psychoanalysis|url=https://www.danceuk.org/news/article/loipa-araujo-leading-cuban-ballerina-discusses-parallels-between-dance-psychoanalysis/|publisher=Dance UK|accessdate=28 February 2014|date=February 15, 2011}}</ref> A sister and a brother died c. 2008.<ref name=Seidman2011>{{cite news|last=Seidman|first=Carrie|title=Cuba's Loipa Araújo: The rock star of ballet teachers|url=http://arts.heraldtribune.com/2011-08-14/section/cubas-loipa-araujo-the-rock-star-of-ballet-teachers/|accessdate=28 February 2014|newspaper=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]|date=August 14, 2011}}</ref> She trained at the [[Cuban National Ballet School|Ballet School of the Sociedad Pro-Arte Musical de La Habana]] and at the [[Alicia Alonso]] Ballet Academy.
==Career== Araújo joined the BNC in 1955 (1959 is also mentioned)<ref name=Newman2011>{{cite journal|last=Newman|first=Barbara|title=Teacher's Wisdom: Loipa Araújo|journal=Dance Magazine|date=March 2011|url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/March-2011/Teachers-Wisdom-Loipa-Arajo-|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> and was promoted to [[principal ballerina]] in 1965. In 1973, she associated with [[Ballet National de Marseille]] where she again held the position of prima ballerina, becoming a [[muse]] for [[Roland Petit]].<ref name=Seidman2011 /> Araújo was a guest performer with the [[Béjart Ballet]], [[Bolshoi Ballet]], [[Bulgarian National Opera and Ballet]], Maly Theatre, and [[Royal Danish Ballet]].<ref name=ballet.org.uk />
When she was 21 years old, Araújo began teaching at the BNC,<ref name=Seidman2011 /> transitioning in later years to [[ballet master|ballet mistress]]. Other teaching opportunities occurred at the Béjart Ballet, Bolshoi Ballet, [[Maggio Musicale Fiorentino]], [[Opéra National de Bordeaux]], [[Paris Opera Ballet]], [[The Royal Ballet]], [[Royal Danish Ballet]], [[Teatro dell'Opera di Roma]], [[Teatro alla Scala]], and [[Teatro di San Carlo]]. In September 2012, Araújo joined the [[English National Ballet]],<ref name=ballet.org.uk>{{cite web|title=Loipa Araujo|url=http://www.ballet.org.uk/the-company/staff/loipa-arauio/|publisher=English National Ballet|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> where she is the Associate Artistic Director.
Among Araújo's many Cuban honors are the Distinción Por la Cultura Nacional, Medalla Alejo Carpentier, Orden Félix Varela, Premio Anual del [[Gran Teatro de La Habana]], Medalla Fernando Ortiz, Premio Nacional de Danza, Doctora ''Honoris Causa'' en Arte, and Member emeritus [[National Union of Writers and Artists of Cuba]].<ref name=Cabrera2011>{{cite journal|last=Cabrera|first=Miguel|title=Loipa Araújo: Siete décadas de una joya|journal=[[La Jiribilla]]|date=May 28, 2011|url=http://www.lajiribilla.cu/2011/n525_05/525_12.html|accessdate=28 February 2014}}</ref> Her international awards include the Gold Medal (Varna, 1965), Silver Medal (Moscow, 1969), and Gold star at the Champs Elysées Ballet Festival (Paris, 1970). She was honored with the [[Legion of Honour|Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur]] by France in 2011.<ref name=ballet.org.uk />

'''The London School of Philosophy''' is an independent [[adult education]] college located in [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]. It offers part-time non-degree courses on a wide range of topics within [[philosophy]]. It was founded in 2010 by lecturers from Birkbeck College. It is based within [[Conway Hall]], in [[Bloomsbury]].
==History==
In 2009, the long-established School of Continuing Education at [[Birkbeck, University of London]], which specialised in [[extra-mural studies]], was abolished and its activities integrated into the main college. The following year, as part of this re-organisation, the number of part-time philosophy courses for adults was sharply reduced. Seven of Birkbeck's philosophy lecturers responded to the cancellation of their courses by meeting to establish a new college, the London School of Philosophy (LSP).<ref name="LSP1">{{cite web |url=http://londonschoolofphilosophy.org/ |title=Philosophy For the Capital |work=LSP website |accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref> <ref name="ER1">{{cite |title=The London School of Philosophy at Conway Hall|work=Ethical Record (Vol.116 No.9, October 2011) |}}</ref>
The LSP's seven founders organised themselves on a cooperative basis and agreed a constitution in 2010. The first lectures took place in January 2011. A launch event was held on 6 September 2011.<ref name="LSP2">{{cite web |url=http://londonschoolofphilosophy.org/?page_id=477 |title=Launch Event |work=LSP website |accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref>
==Location== In 2011 the London School of Philosophy announced a collaborative agreement with [[Conway Hall]] to base all its teaching activities there.<ref name="PN">{{cite web |url=http://www.philosophynow.org/issue86/News_September_October_2011 |title=London’s first adult education college devoted entirely to philosophy |work=Philosophy Now (September/October 2011) |accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref>
Conway Hall is a large [[art-deco]] building on Red Lion Square in [[Bloomsbury]], built in 1929. It is the venue for a wide range of concerts, lectures and other cultural events.<ref name="CH">{{cite web |url=http://www.conwayhall.org.uk |title=Conway Hall |work=Conway Hall website |accessdate=2011-11-15}}</ref> The building also houses the Humanist Library,<ref name="HL">{{cite web |url=http://www.conwayhall.org.uk/our-library |title=Library |work=Conway Hall website |accessdate=2014-06-30}}</ref> which includes a sizeable philosophy section.
==Courses== Courses at the college cover topics such as ‘Philosophy and Theatre’, ‘Philosophy of Love’; ‘Existentialism’; and ‘Philosophy and Biology’ alongside others on ethics, aesthetics and the history of philosophy.
==Summer Schools== In 2013 the London School of Philosophy for the first time entered a collaborative arrangement with [[Birkbeck,_University_of_London|Birkbeck]]'s Department of Philosophy and with Conway Hall, to offer a Summer School on philosophy, which was held over several days at the beginning of July.
The LSP's second annual Summer School, in 2014, was a collaboration with [[Heythrop College]] and Conway Hall. The speakers included Professor [[John Cottingham]], Professor [[Keith Ward]], Dr Anna Abram, Dr [[Piers Benn]], Dr [[Stephen Law]] and Dr Adam Stewart-Wallace (all from Heythrop), Dr Shahrar Ali, Dr Keith Barrett and Dr [[Anja Steinbauer]] (from London School of Philosophy) and special guest speakers Dr [[Roger Scruton]], Emeritus Professor [[Richard Norman]] (Kent) and Professor [[Ken Gemes]] (Birkbeck). <ref name="LS">{{cite web |url=http://www.londonschoolofphilosophy.org |title=LSP Summer School |work=LSP website |accessdate=2014-06-30}}</ref>
==Student life== [[File:Bertrand Russell and Conway Hall - geograph.org.uk - 1801595.jpg|thumb|Bust of [[Bertrand Russell]] in front of Conway Hall - geograph.org.uk - 1801595]] As the London School of Philosophy offers only part-time courses, student life is not centralised. The college does not offer [[halls of residence]]. At lunchtimes, LSP students often gather at the open-air Park Café in Red Lion Square Gardens.
==References== <!--See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] for an explanation of how to generate footnotes using the <ref(erences/)> tags--> {{reflist}}
==External links==
<!--Please keep "the official %%% website" wording for Google:--> * [http://londonschoolofphilosophy.org/ londonschoolofphilosophy.org] - The official London School of Philosophy website * [http://www.conwayhall.org.uk/ www.conwayhall.org.uk] - The official Conway Hall website.

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2018}} {{advert|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox dot-com company | name = Mindvalley | logo = Логотип Mindvalley.png | logo_size = 200px | url = {{URL|mindvalley.com/}} | location = [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia | commercial = Yes | num_employees = 202 (2018) | type = [[Online education]] | registration = Required | num_users = 2.5M active users per month | founder = [[Vishen Lakhiani]] | launch_date = {{Start date and age|df=y|2004|03}} | current_status = Active }} '''Mindvalley''' – globe education [[technology company]] founded by [[Vishen Lakhiani]] in 2002. It publishes products focused on "personal spiritual development" and "lifelong learning". One of the educational publishers that provides customized educational content, software, and services about mindfulness, meditation, personal growth, fitness and health.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/business-23372767/business-that-blurs-work-and-play|title=Business that 'blurs work and play'|work=''BBC News''|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref> As of 2018, the company has more 202 employees from 46 countries, and offers products and services based on delivering digital content and technology-enabled learning [[solution]]s to over 135 countries in 60 plus languages.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathycaprino/2017/04/03/if-our-higher-education-system-is-broken-how-can-we-fix-it/|title=If Our Higher Education System Is Broken, How Can We Fix It?|last=Caprino|first=Kathy|work=Forbes|accessdate=1 September 2018}}</ref>
== History == Company was founded by Vishen Lakhiani in [[New York City]] in 2002.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=Https://www.businessinsider.com.au/7-lessons-from-bootstrapping-a-15m-lifestyle-business-2013-1#SQ2Eo43aytAPjLzh.99|title=7 Lessons From Bootstrapping a $15M Lifestyle Business|date=16 January 2013|website=Business Insider}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://mixergy.com/interviews/vishen-lakhiani-mindvalley-interview/|title=How MindValley Founder Built A$40M Company With Only $700 – with Vishen Lakhiani |work=Mixergy|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref>
Mindvalley started as a digital [[Publishing|publishing company]], and then evolved to education company offering teachings programs on mindfulness, meditation, personal growth, fitness and health.
The first flagship product published by Mindvalley was [http://www.silvalifesystem.com/ the Silva Life System], which was their primary offering during that time.<ref name=":1" />
In 2004 the company headquarters relocated from New York to [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/capital/story/20141008-wooing-reluctant-relocators|title=Luring workers to the middle of nowhere|last=Rayasam|first=Renuka|date=9 October 2014|publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ua/books?id=hNnOCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA115&lpg=PA115&dq=vishen+lakhiani++leave+us++after+11+september&source=bl&ots=RnNCQDcg77&sig=LIix1dvvtvwMvg-o2daGMxLQqHc&hl=uk&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwizs_GZiZXdAhUJ2ywKHZQVBNsQ6AEwCnoECAkQAQ#v=onepage&q=vishen%20lakhiani%20%20leave%20us%20%20after%2011%20september&f=false|title=The Code of the Extraordinary Mind: 10 Unconventional Laws to Redefine Your Life and Succeed On Your Own Terms|last=Lakhiani|first=Vishen|publisher=|year=2016 р|isbn=|location=|pages=288 стр.|language=}}</ref>
In 2013 company`s revenues past $15 million a year (50 million in Malaysian Ringgit).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businessinsider.com.au/7-lessons-from-bootstrapping-a-15m-lifestyle-business-2013-1|title=7 Lessons From Bootstrapping a $15M Lifestyle Business|last=Council|first=Young Entrepreneur|date=16 January 2013|work=Business Insider Australia|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref> Nowdays Mindvalley has revenues of more than $20 million annually.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/capital/story/20141008-wooing-reluctant-relocators|title=Luring workers to the middle of nowhere|last=Rayasam|first=Renuka|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref>
== Applications == In 2015 was released meditation app [http://www.omvana.com/ Omvana]. Its library contains thousands of meditations, and about 75 of those are free.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mindful.org/free-mindfulness-apps-worthy-of-your-attention/|title=Free Mindfulness Apps Worthy of Your Attention|last=M. NEWMAN|first=KIRA|date=6 April 2017|website=|publisher=FOUNDATION FOR A MINDFUL SOCIETY|dead-url=}}</ref> In 2018 it reaches more than 100 000 installations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.omvana.mixer&hl=en|title=Omvana: Meditation, Yoga Sleep|website=}}</ref>
In 2016 founder Vishen Lakhiani’s book “The Code of The Extraordinary Mind” was published by [[Rodale, Inc.|Rodale Inc]]. It went on to reach #4 on [[The New York Times Best Seller list|the New York Times Business Best-sellers list]]. In 2017 the book received a boost due to being features on Amazon Prime for on Sep 27 2017 hit the #1 spot on the [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] charts for all books on Kindle globally. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/best-sellers/2016/05/29/advice-how-to-and-miscellaneous/|title=Advice, How-To & Miscellaneous Books - Best Sellers - May 29, 2016 - The New York Times|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/978-1-62336-708-4|title=Nonfiction Book Review: The Code of the Extraordinary Mind: 10 Unconventional Laws to Redefine Your Life and Succeed on Your Own Terms by Vishen Lakhiani. Rodale, $26.99 (256p) ISBN 978-1-62336-708-4|work=PublishersWeekly.com|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en}}</ref>
In 2017 it was created [https://www.mindvalley.com/quests/ Quest], app was touted as a solution for our information-thirsty paired with our modern busy lifestyles. The app was tailored to help individuals absorb life changing knowledge in 20-minute time intervals or less, with actionable advice from personal growth gurus such as [[Robin Sharma]], [[Eric Edmeades]] and Lisa Nichols.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://e27.co/captains-log-july-31-ofo-rides-into-thailand-and-mindvalley-launches-education-platform-20170731/|title=Captain's Log, July 31: ofo rides into Thailand, and Mindvalley launches education platform|last=McSpadden|first=Kevin|date=31 July 2017|website=}}</ref> Nowadays there are approximately 30 English-language courses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mindvalley.com/|title=A Global School For Humanity|website=Mindvalley|accessdate=6 September 2018}}</ref>
In 2017 Mindvalley launched Mindvalley University City Campus, a month-long program where people of all ages move to a live campus in a specific cities for an entire month of educational and community activities. The first city campus took place in [[Barcelona]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehedonistmagazine.com/2018/08/31/vishen-lakhiani-the-code-of-the-extraordinary-mind/|title=Vishen Lakhiani {{!}} The Code of the Extraordinary Mind|date=2018-08-31|work=The Hedonist Magazine|access-date=2018-09-25|language=en-US}}</ref>. In 2017 with 300 people. In 2017 it expanded to 1100 people and took place in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] while attracting such teachers as Sri Sri Ravishankar, Dr. Shefali Tsabary and Jim Kwik.
== Awards and recognition ==
* Vishen Lakhiani, founder of Mindvalley, chosen for the SME & Entrepreneurship Business Award, dubbed the SEBAA's Most Strategic Entrepreneur of the year for 2017 and was inducted into the Hall of Fame .<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sebaasia.com/|title=The SME & Entrepreneurship Business Awards.|website=}}</ref> * In 2017 Mindvalley`s first [[documentary film]] on transformational education called ‘Live Your Quest’ was nominated for a regional [[Emmy Award]] for Best Director for their. Its director Nick Nanton was nominated for Best Director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pressnewsroom.com/nick-nanton-and-dna-films-earn-emmy-nomination-for-documentary-live-your-quest/|title=Nick Nanton and DNA Films® Earn Emmy® Nomination for Documentary, "Live Your Quest" – PressNewsRoom|website=''pressnewsroom.com''|access-date=10 September 2018}}</ref> * Omvana is the No. 1 Health and Fitness app in 35+ countries in the [[ITunes Store]] . Omvana brings you 500+ tracks of world's top transformational audios to enhance every area of your life.<ref>{{Cite web|url=Http://www.omvana.com|title=Omvana by Mindvalley|website=}}</ref> In mid-2014, Mindvalley's second mobile app, Dormio, became the second most downloaded Health and Fitness app in the US.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bradauerbach/2017/12/23/mindvalley-and-its-a-fest-offer-festival-goers-a-massage-for-the-brain/|title=Mindvalley And Its A-Fest Offer Festival Goers A Massage for the Brain|last=Auerbach|first=Brad|work=Forbes|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref> * The HR Excellence Awards, that is the largest HR celebration in [[Asia]], awarded Mindvalley with the Gold for Excellence in Workplace Well-being in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.humanresourcesonline.net/events/live-hr-excellence-awards-2015-malaysia/|title=Live: HR Excellence Awards 2015, Malaysia|website=}}</ref> * With a focus on user experience, clean minimalism in design, and intuitive navigation, [[web design]] of Mindvalley was chosen as the Best Web Design by Web Design File in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=[http://www.webdesignfile.com/|title=Web design file|website=}}</ref> * Mindvalley ranked 1st place in [[Nicereply Customer Happiness Awards]] 2014, receiving the highest rating average in Asia. According to the research, 79% of all 3354 ratings was the highest score 10. This award measures a company's customer satisfaction levels, and uses its own scoring formula, along with CSAT, Net Promoter Score (NPS) & Customer Effort Score.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nicereply.com/awards-2014/Mindvalley/|title=Nicereply Customer Happiness Awards 2014|website=}}</ref> * [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc Magazine]] awarded Mindvalley`s office in [[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]] as the Coolest Office of the Year in 2012. The Magazine empasize "a mixture of cultural references from Superman in flight to a googly-eyed dragon on a marble table" as a result of employing people from over 31 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/ss/worlds-coolest-offices/facebook-contest-winners|title=World`s Coolest Officcesː Your Pics|website=}}</ref> * Every year since 2008 Mindvalley is named the most freedom-centered organisation in the world by [https://www.worldblu.com/ The WorldBlu List of Freedom-Centered Workplaces.] The assessment evaluates the overall design of an organization along a fear-based to freedom-centered continuum in three core areas: leadership, individual performance and systems, and processes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.worldblu.com/awardee-profiles/2016.php|title=Cultural transformation in organisations|website=}}</ref>
== Related business == [http://www.mindvalleyrussian.com/ Mindvalley for the Russian-speaking market.] About 30 programs of various topics, weekly mediation in [[Moscow Time|Moscow time]] are offered.
[https://omnama.it/ Mindvalley for the Italian market.] In addition to varied courses in Italian, the service offers the purchase of e-books.
[https://www.afest.com/ A-Fest] is an event that involves more than 2000 people from 50 countries, which takes place twice a year. The purpose of the festival is to unite, grow and learn from the best teachers of the world.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uproxx.com/life/mindvalley-a-fest-jamaica/|title=A-Fest Is The Otherworldly Union of Festivals And Learning Conferences|date=13 February 2018|work=UPROXX|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref> Past destinations include [[Bali]], [[Ibiza]], [[Dubrovnik]], [[Mykonos]] and the [[Riviera Maya|Mayan Riviera]] in Mexico.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/bradauerbach/2017/12/23/mindvalley-and-its-a-fest-offer-festival-goers-a-massage-for-the-brain/|title=Mindvalley And Its A-Fest Offer Festival Goers A Massage for the Brain|last=Auerbach|first=Brad|work=Forbes|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref> The next event will be held in [[Bali]], Indonesia.
[https://www.mindvalley.com/u/ The Mindvalley U] is a one-month transformational event that takes place once a year in different locations. The purpose of the event is to provide skills for personal and business growth.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/kathycaprino/2017/04/03/if-our-higher-education-system-is-broken-how-can-we-fix-it/|title=If Our Higher Education System Is Broken, How Can We Fix It?|last=Caprino|first=Kathy|work=Forbes|access-date=12 September 2018}}</ref> Mindvalley U changes its location annually. In 2018 was in [[Estonia]].
{{MOOC}}
