{{Other uses|Miss America (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox company | name = Miss America | logo = Miss America Logo.jpg | type = Beauty pageant | predecessor = {{start date|1920|09|25}}
Atlantic City, New Jersey, U.S. (as The Fall Frolic) | founded = {{start date and age|1921|09|08}}
Atlantic City, New Jersey, U.S. | key_people = [[Gretchen Carlson]], Chairwoman[https://www.nbcnews.com/pop-culture/tv/gretchen-carlson-elected-miss-america-chair-amid-sexist-email-scandal-n833871 Gretchen Carlson elected as Miss America chair after sexist email scandal] | hq_location_city = [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], [[New Jersey]] | hq_location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | website = {{URL|https://missamerica.org/}} }} '''Miss America''' is an annual competition that is open to women from the [[United States]] between the ages of 17 and 25.{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/miss-america-raises-maximum-age-of-competitors-to-25/2018/01/07/dc9bf9ec-f3c8-11e7-9af7-a50bc3300042_story.html|title=Miss America raises maximum age of competitors to 25|last=Associated Press|first=|date=7 January 2018|work=Washington Post|access-date=21 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180121185835/https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/miss-america-raises-maximum-age-of-competitors-to-25/2018/01/07/dc9bf9ec-f3c8-11e7-9af7-a50bc3300042_story.html?utm_term=.1396f15afb56|archive-date=2018-01-21|dead-url=yes}} Originating in 1921 as a "bathing beauty revue", the contest is now judged on competitors' talent performances and interviews. As of 2018, there is no longer a swimsuit portion to the contest, or consideration of physical appearance.{{cite news |last1=Haag |first1=Mathtew, et. al. |title=Miss America Ends Swimsuit Competition, Aiming to Evolve in ‘This Cultural Revolution’ |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/05/business/miss-america-swimsuit.html |accessdate=5 June 2018 |publisher=New York Times |date=5 June 2018}} Miss America travels about 20,000 miles a month, changing her location every 24 to 48 hours, touring the nation and promoting her particular platform of interest.{{cite journal|last=Watson|first=Ellwood|first2=Darcy|last2=Martin|title=The Miss America Pageant: Pluralism, Femininity, and Cinderella All in One|journal=Journal of Popular Culture|publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]]|year=2000|volume=1|issue=34|pages=105–126}} The winner is crowned by the previous year's titleholder. The current titleholder, [[Miss America 2019]], is Miss New York 2018, [[Nia Franklin]], who was crowned on September 9, 2018, by her predecessor [[Cara Mund]] ([[Miss America 2018]]). == Overview == [[File:Margaret Gorman 4.jpg|thumb|175 px|Margaret Gorman, Miss America 1921]] On February 1, 1919, there was a beauty pageant held in the Chu Chin Chow Ball at the Hotel des Artistes in [[New York City]]. The winner, [[Edith Hyde Robbins Macartney]], was called "Miss America." Neither the title nor this pageant were related to the current "Miss American Pageant" which would develop a year later in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]].[https://www.nytimes.com/1978/04/28/archives/obituary-3-no-title.html "Deaths: Macartney—Edith Hyde"]. ''New York Times'', April 28, 1978.[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A05EFD81F38E533A25756C2A9679C946195D6CF&nytmobile=0&legacy=true "Miss Acheson Weds Canadian Captain"] ''New York Times'', Jan. 25, 1920.Anderson, Susan Heller, and David W. Dunlap. [https://www.nytimes.com/1984/12/06/nyregion/new-york-day-by-day-see-through-pantaloons-circa-1919.html "See-Through Pantaloons, Circa 1919"]. ''New York Times'', Dec. 6, 1984.[http://www.greatreporter.com/content/first-real-miss-america "The First Real Miss America"]. Greatreporter.com, Feb. 2, 2006Senn, Bryan. ''Golden Horrors: An Illustrated Critical Filmography of Terror Cinema, 1931-1939'', p. 67. Rather, the origins of the "Miss America Pageant" lie in an event entitled ''The Fall Frolic'' which was held on September 25, 1920, in Atlantic City. This event was designed to bring business to the Boardwalk: "three hundred and fifty gaily decorated rolling wicker chairs were pushed along the parade route. Three hundred and fifty men pushed the chairs. However, the main attractions were the young 'maidens' who sat in the rolling chairs, headed by a Miss Ernestine Cremona, who was dressed in a flowing white robe and represented 'Peace.'"{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/peopleevents/e_first.html|title=People & Events: The First Miss America Beauty Pageant, 1921|publisher=[[PBS]]}} The event was so successful that ''The Businessmen's League'' planned to repeat it the following year as a [[beauty pageant]] or a "bather's revue" (to capitalize on the popularity of newspaper-based beauty contests that used photo submissions). The event was scheduled to take place the week-end following Labor Day, to encourage summer visitors to stay in Atlantic City. Thus, "newspapers as far west as Pittsburgh and as far south as Washington, D.C., were asked to sponsor local beauty contests. The winners would participate in the Atlantic City contest. If the local newspaper would pay for the winner's wardrobe, the Atlantic City Businessmen's League would pay for the contestant's travel to compete in the Inter-City Beauty Contest." Herb Test, a "newspaperman", coined the term for the winner: "Miss America." On September 8, 1921, 100,000 people gathered at the Boardwalk to watch the contestants from [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Pittsburgh]], [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]], [[Ocean City, New Jersey|Ocean City]], [[Camden, New Jersey|Camden]], [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]], [[New York City|New York]], and [[Philadelphia]]. The 16-year-old winner from [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Margaret Gorman]], was crowned the "Golden Mermaid" and won $100. The pageant continued consistently over the next eight decades except for the years 1928–1932, when it was temporarily shut down due to financial problems associated with the [[Great Depression]] and suggestions that it promoted "loose morals."{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh//amex/missamerica/timeline/timeline2.html|title=Miss America Timeline: 1901–1950|publisher=[[PBS]]}} With its revival in 1933, 15-year-old [[Marian Bergeron]] won, prompting future contestants to be between the ages of 18 and 26. In 1935, Lenora Slaughter was hired to "re-invent" the pageant and served for 32 years as its Director. By 1938, a talent section was added to the competition, and contestants were required to have a chaperone. In 1940, the title officially became "The Miss America Pageant" and the pageant was held in Atlantic City's Convention Hall. In 1944, compensation for "Miss America" switched from "furs and movie contracts" to college scholarships, an idea generally credited to [[Jean Bartel]], Miss America 1943.{{cite book |first=Kate |last=Shindle |authorlink=Kate Shindle |title=Being Miss America: Behind the Rhinestone Curtain |location=Austin |publisher=University of Texas Press |year=2014 |series=Discovering America |isbn=978-0-292-73921-5 |pages=13–14 }} During the early years of the pageant, under the directorship of Lenora Slaughter, it became segregated via rule number seven that stated: "contestants must be of good health and [[Jim Crow laws|of the white race]]." Rule number seven was abolished in 1950.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=OKswV1U_M5QC&pg=PA204 |title=Race and Multiraciality in Brazil and the United States: Converging Paths? |first=G. Reginald|last= Daniel |publisher=Pennsylvania State University |accessdate=September 22, 2013|isbn=978-0-271-04554-2 |year=2006 }} [[Miss New York]] 1945, [[Bess Myerson]], the only [[American Jews|Jewish American]] winner to date, became [[Miss America 1945]] and faced [[antisemitism]] during her time as Miss America, leading to a cutback in her official duties.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/filmmore/pt.html|title=PBS American Experience: Miss America Transcript|date=2002|publisher= [[PBS]] [[American Experience]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/06/nyregion/bess-myerson-miss-america-and-new-york-official-tarnished-in-scandal-dies.html?emc=edit_th_20150106&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=19530762&_r=2|title=Bess Myerson, New Yorker of Beauty, Wit, Service and Scandal, Dies at 90|last= Nemy|first=Enid|date=January 5, 2015|publisher= New York Times}}{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-bess-myerson-20150105-story.html#page=1|title=Bess Myerson, Miss America who rose in politics and fell in scandal, dies at 90|last= Woo|first=Elaine|date=January 5, 2015|publisher= [[Los Angeles Times]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/bess-myerson-beauty-queen-turned-nyc-public-servant-dies-at-90-1420497010|title=Bess Myerson, Beauty Queen Turned NYC Public Servant, Dies at 90|last= Hollander|first=Sophia|date=January 5, 2015|publisher=Wall Street Journal}}{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20096618,00.html|title=Downfall of An American Idol|last=Green|first=Michelle|date=June 29, 1987|publisher= [[People Magazine]]}} Although there were [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]], [[Latino (demonym)|Latina]], and [[Asian Americans|Asian-American]] contestants, there were no [[African Americans|African-American]] contestants for fifty years (African-Americans appeared in musical numbers as far back as 1923, however, when they were cast as slaves).{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/peopleevents/e_inclusion.html|title=Miss America, People & Events: Breaking the Color Line at the Pageant |publisher=[[PBS]]}}{{cite book| author=Shirley Jennifer Lim| title=A Feeling of Belonging: Asian-American Women's Popular Culture, 1930–1960| publisher=NYU Press| year=2007| pages=126–127| isbn=0-8147-5193-8}}{{cite book| author=[[Sarah Banet-Weiser]]| title=The Most Beautiful Girl in the World: Beauty Pageants and National Identity| publisher=University of California Press| date=September 30, 1999| pages=153–166| isbn=0-520-21791-8}} In 1970, however, [[Cheryl Browne]], [[Miss Iowa]] 1970,{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/filmmore/pt.html|title=Miss America, People & Events: Transcript|publisher=[[PBS]]|access-date=2016-03-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160330135726/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/filmmore/pt.html|archive-date=2016-03-30|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.missiowa.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=146&Itemid=554|title=Former Miss Iowa Titleholders|publisher=}} competed as the first African-American contestant in the [[Miss America 1971]] pageant. She also participated in one of the last [[United Service Organizations|USO]]-Miss America tours in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]].{{cite web |url=http://qctimes.com/lifestyles/history-follows-former-miss-iowa-first-black-pageant-winner-recalls/article_11e551e5-dc86-5ed1-8447-a224562ad89e.html |title=History follows former Miss Iowa First black pageant winner recalls her crowning moment |accessdate= |last=Davis |first=Shirley |date=2000-10-19 |publisher=''[[Quad-City Times]]'' }} A decade later in 1983, [[Miss New York]] (and Miss Syracuse) 1983, [[Vanessa Williams]] (the first [[African Americans|African-American]] woman to win the competition as [[Miss America 1984]]), faced discrimination in response to her win and later resigned under pressure due to a scandal involving nude photographs. Three decades after these events, [[Miss New York]] (and Miss Syracuse) 2013, [[Nina Davuluri]], the first [[Indian Americans|Indian-American]] woman to win the crown as [[Miss America 2014]], faced [[Xenophobia|xenophobic]] and [[Racism|racist]] comments in social media when she won.{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/09/21/vanessa-williams-the-first-black-miss-america-on-nina-davuluri-and-racism.html|title=Vanessa Williams, the First Black Miss America, On Nina Davuluri and Racism|last=Stern|first=Marlow|date=September 21, 2013|publisher= [[The Daily Beast]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.atlanticcityweekly.com/news_and_views/vanessa-on-valentine-s-day/article_f05e75df-87ee-5ade-96b3-d63d66e03ace.html|title=Vanessa on Valentine's Day:The most successful Miss America in the entertainment world, Vanessa Williams brings her love of the stage to Caesars on Feb. 14.|date=2014-02-12|publisher=Atlantic City Weekly}} Two years later at the [[Miss America 2016]] pageant, former Miss America CEO Sam Haskell apologized to Vanessa Williams (who was serving as head judge) for what was said to her during the events of 1984.{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2015/09/vanessa-williams-miss-america-apology-2015.html |title=Vanessa Williams Finally Got Her Miss America Apology |accessdate=2015-09-17 |last=Fitz-Gerald |first=Sean |date=2015-09-14 |publisher= New York Magazine }}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/15/arts/television/vanessa-williams-returns-to-miss-america-and-receives-an-apology.html?_r=0 |title=Vanessa Williams Returns to Miss America and Receives an Apology |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Rogers |first=Katie |date=2015-09-14 |publisher=''New York Times'' }}{{cite web |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/09/vanessa-williams-apology-miss-america-2015 |title=Watch Vanessa Williams Finally Receive an Apology at the Miss America 2016 Pageant |accessdate=2015-09-13 |last=Robinson |first=Joanna |date=2015-09-14 |publisher= ''Vanity Fair'' }} In 2018, the pageant ended the swimsuit portion of the competition. [[Gretchen Carlson]], the organization’s chairwoman, who was Miss America in 1989, explained on ABC's ''[[Good Morning America]]'': “We are not going to judge you on your outward appearance... We are moving it forward and evolving it in this cultural revolution.”{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/05/business/miss-america-swimsuit.html|title=Miss America Ends Swimsuit Competition, Aiming to Evolve in ‘This Cultural Revolution’|date=June 5, 2018|newspaper=The New York Times}} == History == === 1921–1967 === [[Margaret Gorman]], Miss District of Columbia, was declared "The Most Beautiful Bathing Girl in America" in 1921 at the age of 16 and was recognized as the first "Miss America" when she returned to compete the next year. The contest that year was won by [[Mary Katherine Campbell]] ([[Miss Ohio]]), who won again in 1923.[https://web.archive.org/web/20150210181621/http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/1920/1923.aspx Mary Katherine Campbell] She returned to compete a third time in 1924 but placed as first runner-up that year, and pageant rules were then amended to prevent anyone from winning more than once. Beginning in 1940, [[Bob Russell (television presenter)|Bob Russell]] served as the first official host of the pageant. In 1941, Mifauny Shunatona, [[Miss Oklahoma]], became the first [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] contestant.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/mar/02/local/me-chee2 |title=Yun Tau Chee, 73; Miss Hawaii of 1948, First Asian in Miss America Pageant – Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=September 4, 1987 |accessdate=September 22, 2013 |first=Elaine |last=Woo}} In 1945, [[Bess Myerson]] became the first [[American Jews|Jewish-American]] and the first [[Miss New York]]{{cite web|url=http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/1940/1945.aspx |title=Bess Myerson Biography (Miss America 1945) |publisher=[[Miss America Organization]] |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150213110152/http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/1940/1945.aspx |archivedate=2015-02-13 |df= }} (competing as Miss New York City, a competition organized by a local radio station) to win the Miss America pageant as [[Miss America 1945]]. As the only Jewish contestant, Myerson was encouraged by the pageant directors to change her name to "Bess Meredith"{{cite web|url=http://www.patriciamorrisroe.com/sites/default/files/articles/Bess-and-the-Mess.pdf |title=Bess and the Mess: Myerson's Slide Into Scandal (pp. 34–35) |last=Morrisroe |first=Patricia |date=March 30, 1987 |publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} or "Beth Merrick", but she refused. After winning the title (and as a Jewish Miss America), Myerson received few endorsements and later recalled that "I couldn't even stay in certain hotels […] there would be signs that read no coloreds, no Jews, no dogs. I felt so rejected. Here I was chosen to represent American womanhood and then America treated me like this." She thus cut short her Miss America tour and instead traveled with the [[Anti-Defamation League]]. In this capacity, she spoke against discrimination in a talk entitled, "You Can't Be Beautiful and Hate." In 1948, Irma Nydia Vasquez, the first [[Miss Puerto Rico]], became the first [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Latina]] contestant.{{cite web|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/missamerica/cheryl-browne-was-the-first-african-american-contestant-as-miss/article_9161214a-b0d5-11e2-aad9-001a4bcf887a.html?TNNoMobile|title=Cheryl Browne was the first African-American contestant as Miss Iowa in 1970.|publisher=}}{{cite web |url=http://pageantcenter.com/news/2009/miss-america-pageant/miss_america_pageant-news-6-2009.html |title=Miss America Pageant News |publisher=Pageantcenter.com |date=January 30, 2010 |accessdate=September 22, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927102409/http://pageantcenter.com/news/2009/miss-america-pageant/miss_america_pageant-news-6-2009.html |archivedate=September 27, 2013 |df= }} In addition, in 1948, Yun Tau Chee, the first [[Miss Hawaii]], was also the first [[Asian Americans|Asian-American]] contestant. [[Miss America 1949]], [[Jacque Mercer]], was married and divorced during her reign; after this, a rule was enacted requiring Miss America contestants to sign a certification that they have never been married or pregnant.{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-09-17/features/9909170275_1_miss-america-america-contestants-pageant|title=Pageant tightens grip on its ideals|publisher=}} Starting in 1950, although the pageant continued to be in September, the Miss America title changed to "post-dated", thus that year's pageant winner became Miss America 1951, and there was no Miss America 1950. The pageant was first [[television|televised]] nationally in 1954, hosted by [[Bob Russell (television presenter)|Bob Russell]]. Future television star [[Lee Meriwether]] was crowned [[Miss America 1955]]. It would also be the last time Russell served as host. He recommended, and was replaced by, [[Bert Parks]], who served as the host for the second televised pageant in 1955 and stayed as host until 1979.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/peopleevents/p_parks.html|title=American Experience – Miss America – People & Events|publisher=}} Television viewership peaked during the early 1960s, when it was the highest-rated program on American television.{{cite web| title=Miss America Crowned; What Ever Happened to Beauty Pageants?| author=Bill Gorman| url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2010/01/30/miss-america-crowned-beauty-pageant-tv-ratings-history/40588/|date=January 30, 2010| publisher=TV by the numbers| accessdate=December 15, 2011}} === 1968–2016 === With the rise of [[second-wave feminism]] and the [[Civil and political rights|civil right]]s movement during the 1960s, the Miss America pageant became the subject of a series of protests that attacked it as sexist, racist, and part of U.S. militarism. The first demonstration took place during the [[Miss America 1969]] pageant held on September 7, 1968 (won by [[Miss Illinois]] 1968, [[Judith Ford]]), when about 200 members of the group [[New York Radical Women]] demonstrated as part of the [[Miss America protest]]. In addition, a pamphlet distributed at the protest by [[Robin Morgan]], ''No More Miss America!'', became a source for feminist scholarship.{{cite journal| title=Feminist theory reader: Local and Global Perspectives| author=Carole R. McCann and Seung-Kyung Kim| publisher=Routledge| place=New York| date=July 22, 2009| isbn=0-415-99477-2| pages=90–91}} The protest was co-sponsored by [[Florynce Kennedy]]'s Media Workshop, an activist group she founded in 1966 to protest the media's representation of [[African Americans]], along with the feminist Jeanette Rankin Brigade and the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]].From Robyn Morgan to Atlantic City Mayor Richard Jackson, 28 August 1968: seeking a permit for a peaceful protest. In Morgan papers, Duke University; see http://library.duke.edu/digitalcollections/wlmpc/ Morgan later stated that the Miss America pageant "was chosen as a target for a number of reasons: it has always been a lily-white, racist contest; the winner tours [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]], entertaining the troops as a 'Murder Mascot'; the whole gimmick is one commercial shillgame to sell the sponsor's products. Where else could one find such a perfect combination of American values—racism, militarism, sexism—all packaged in one ‘ideal symbol,’ a woman."Robin Morgan, "The Oldest Front: On Freedom for Women," ''Liberation, an Independent Monthly'', Vol. 13, No. 5, October 1968, pg. 34 The protesters compared the pageant to a county fair where livestock are judged.{{cite web|url=http://officialnj350.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Miss-America.-Atlantic-City.-It-Happened-Here-New-Jersey.-Image-Credits.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328231056/http://officialnj350.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/Miss-America.-Atlantic-City.-It-Happened-Here-New-Jersey.-Image-Credits.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=March 28, 2015|title=It Happened Here in New Jersey: Miss America|accessdate=March 5, 2015|publisher=[[Kean University]] and the New Jersey Historical Commission}}{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=94240375&from=mobile|title=Pageant Protest Sparked Bra-Burning Myth|last=Greenfieldboyce|first=Nell|date=September 5, 2008|publisher= [[NPR]]}} They thus crowned a [[sheep]] as Miss America and symbolically destroyed a number of feminine products, including false eyelashes, high-heeled shoes, curlers, hairspray, makeup, [[girdle]]s, [[corset]]s, and [[bra]]s.{{cite journal | author=Dow, Bonnie J. |title=Feminism, Miss America, and Media Mythology |journal=Rhetoric & Public Affairs |volume=6 |issue=1 |date= Spring 2003 |pages=127–149 |doi=10.1353/rap.2003.0028}} Burning the contents of a trash can was suggested, but a permit was unobtainable; news media seized on the similarity between [[Draft evasion#Vietnam War|draft resisters]] burning draft cards and women burning their bras. In fact, there was no bra burning, nor did anyone remove her bra.{{cite book|last=Duffett |first=Judith |title=WLM vs. Miss America |work=Voice of the Women's Liberation Movement |date=October 1968 }}{{Cite news|url=http://equalityarchive.com/history/protesting-miss-america/|title=Protesting Miss America {{!}} Equality Archive|date=2015-09-22|work=Equality Archive|access-date=2017-03-09}} The [[Women's liberation movement|Women's Liberation Front]] later demonstrated at the [[Miss America 1971]] pageant. [[Miss Iowa]] 1970, [[Cheryl Browne]], became the first [[African Americans|African American]] contestant in the competition's history during the [[Miss America 1971]] pageant (September 12, 1970).{{cite web|title=Television in Review|last=Musel|first=Robert|date=1970-08-26|publisher=''[[The Bryan Times]]'' p. 16 ([[United Press International]])}}{{cite web|url=|title=Black New Yorker chosen Miss Iowa|date=1970-07-05|publisher=''[[The Register-Guard]]''}} She drew attention from reporters and from security personnel in Atlantic City who maintained a visible presence during pageant rehearsals. Browne was not a finalist, however, losing to future media personality, [[Miss Texas]] 1970, [[Phyllis George]]. In August 1971, Browne traveled to [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]] with George, [[Miss Nevada]] 1970, Vicky Jo Todd, [[Miss New Jersey]] 1970, [[Hela Yungst]], [[Miss Arizona]] 1970, Karen Shields, [[Miss Arkansas]] 1970, Donna Connelly, and [[Miss Texas]] 1970 (George's replacement), Belinda Myrick.{{cite web|title=People in News|last=[[Associated Press]]|first=|date=1971-08-11|publisher=''[[Kentucky New Era]]'' p. 23}} They participated in a 22-day [[United Service Organizations]] tour for [[Role of the United States in the Vietnam War#Vietnamization, 1969–75|American troops that]] began in [[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comanchero.org/pictures59.htm|title=Photographs by Paul Cauley, 1971 Door Gunner, A Co 101st Avn (Text by Belinda Myrick-Barnett)|last=Cauley|first=Paul|date=1971|publisher=Paul Cauley}} Browne later commented that she thought "it was one of the last Miss America groups to go to Vietnam." [[Miss Arkansas]] 1980, [[Lencola Sullivan]], finished the [[Miss America 1981]] pageant (September 6, 1980) as fourth runner-up, making her the first African American contestant to place in the top five. A few years later, [[Vanessa Williams]] ([[Miss New York]] 1983) won the title of [[Miss America 1984]] on September 17, 1983, making her the first African American woman to wear the crown.{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/african-american-usa-crowned-1983-article-1.2353418 |title=Vanessa Williams is crowned the first African-American Miss America in 1983 |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Singleton |first=Don |date=1983-09-18 |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' }} Williams later commented that she was one of five minority contestants that year, noting that ballet dancer [[Deneen Graham]] "had already had a cross burned on her front yard because she was the first black [[Miss North Carolina]] [1983]."{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2012/05/10/152422159/vanessa-williams-on-scandals-tv-and-her-mom |title=Vanessa Williams On Scandals, TV And Her Mom |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Martin |first=Michael |date=2010-05-10 |publisher=NPR (National Public Radio) }} She also pointed out that "[[Suzette Charles]] was the first runner-up, and she was biracial. But when the press started, when I would go out on the – on the tour and do my appearances, and people would come up and say they never thought they'd see the day that it would happen; when people would want to shake my hand, and you'd see tears in their eyes, and they'd say, I never thought I'd see it in my lifetime – that's when, you know, it was definitely a very special honor." Williams' reign as Miss America was not without its challenges and controversies, however. For the first time in pageant history, a reigning Miss America was the target of death threats and hate mail.{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/missamerica/peopleevents/e_inclusion.html |title=People & Events: Breaking the Color Line at the Pageant |publisher=PBS}} Williams [[Vanessa Williams and Miss America|was forced to resign seven weeks prior to the end of her time as Miss America]], however, after the unauthorized publication of nude photos in ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]].''{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20088398,00.html |title=Vanessa's Story |accessdate=2015-09-14 |last=Eady |first=Brenda |date=1984-08-06 |publisher=''People Magazine'' }}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/miss-america-firsts-nina-davuluri-vanessa-williams-and-more/2013/09/16/b6bbfd58-1d8f-11e3-8685-5021e0c41964_gallery.html#photo=5 |title=Miss America firsts: Nina Davuluri, Vanessa Williams and more |publisher=The Washington Post |accessdate=September 22, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/own-master-class/How-Vanessa-Williams-Endured-Her-Miss-America-Scandal-Video |title=How Vanessa Williams Endured Her Miss America Scandal |publisher=[[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|OWN]] |accessdate=July 15, 2014}} First runner-up, [[Miss New Jersey]] 1983, [[Suzette Charles]] replaced her for the final weeks of Williams' reign.Chira, Susan. She has also lived in Brookville, Long Island
[https://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F10A1FFA3A5C0C7A8DDDA00894DB484D81 "TO FIRST BLACK MISS AMERICA, VICTORY IS A MEANS TO AN END"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 19, 1983. Accessed December 4, 2007. "Her home is in Mays Landing, 15 miles west of Atlantic City, the site of the contest." Thirty-two years after she resigned however, Vanessa Williams [[Vanessa Williams and Miss America|returned to the Miss America stage]] on September 13, 2015, for the [[Miss America 2016]] pageant as head judge (where [[Miss Georgia (U.S. state)|Miss Georgia]] 2015, [[Betty Cantrell]], won the crown).{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wdGyU0GmfaI|title=Miss America 2016 – Vanessa Williams – Oh How the Years Go By (9-13-15)|accessdate=2015-09-22|last=|first=|date=2015-09-13|publisher=Miss America 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/video/vanessa-williams-returning-miss-america-scandal-33677692|title=Vanessa Williams on Returning to Miss America After Scandal|author=ABC News|work=ABC News|accessdate=September 11, 2015}} The pageant began with former Miss America CEO Sam Haskell issuing an apology to Williams, telling her that although "none of us currently in the organization were involved then, on behalf of today's organization, I want to apologize to you and to your mother, Miss Helen Williams. I want to apologize for anything that was said or done that made you feel any less the Miss America you are and the Miss America you always will be." [[Suzette Charles]] (Williams' replacement) said in an interview with ''[[Inside Edition]]'' that she was perplexed over the apology and suggested that it was given for the purpose of ratings.{{cite web|url=http://www.insideedition.com/headlines/11900-beauty-queen-who-won-vanessa-williams-crown-miss-america-apology-was-about-ratings|title=Beauty Queen Who Won Vanessa Williams' Crown: Miss America Apology Was About Ratings|accessdate=2015-09-18|last=Inside Edition|first=|date=2015-09-14|publisher=Inside Edition}} In 1985, [[Miss Utah]] 1984, [[Sharlene Wells Hawkes]], became the first foreign-born, bilingual Miss America, as she was born in [[Asunción]], [[Paraguay]].{{cite web|url=http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/1980/1985.aspx |title=Miss America : 1985 |work=Miss America |accessdate=2014-02-07 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324191416/http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/1980/1985.aspx |archivedate=2016-03-24 |df= }} [[Miss Alabama]] 1994, [[Heather Whitestone]], won the [[Miss America 1995|1995 pageant]] becoming the first [[Hearing loss|deaf]] Miss America (she lost most of her hearing at the age of 18 months).{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/19/us/first-deaf-miss-america.html |title=First Deaf Miss America – New York Times |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=September 19, 1994 |accessdate=September 22, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/miss-america-firsts-nina-davuluri-vanessa-williams-and-more/2013/09/16/b6bbfd58-1d8f-11e3-8685-5021e0c41964_gallery.html#photo=6 |title=Miss America firsts: Nina Davuluri, Vanessa Williams and more |publisher=The Washington Post |accessdate=September 22, 2013}} At the [[Miss America 1999]] pageant held on September 19, 1998, [[Nicole Johnson (Miss America)|Nicole Johnson]] ([[Miss Virginia]] 1998) became the first Miss America with [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]] and the first contestant to publicize an insulin pump.{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/1998-10-05/living/25763635_1_insulin-pumps-diabetes-blood-sugar |title=A Crown, Scepter & Insulin Pump The New Miss America, Nicole Johnson, Has Drawn Attention To The Device, Which Frees Diabetics From The Strict Scheduling Of Conventional Insulin Regimens. - Philly.com |publisher=Articles.philly.com |date=October 5, 1998 |accessdate=September 22, 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=HR_KNKoBV9oC&pg=PA43&lpg=PA43&dq=%22first+miss+america+with+diabetes%22#v=onepage&q=%22first%20miss%20america%20with%20diabetes%22&f=false |title=Insulin Pump Therapy Demystified: An Essential Guide for Everyone Pumping|first=Gabrielle |last=Kaplan-Mayer |publisher=Marlowe & Co. |year=2003 |accessdate=September 22, 2013|isbn=0-7867-3068-4 }} Around the same time, Miss America officials announced they had lifted the ban on contestants who were divorced or had had an abortion. This rule change, however, was rescinded and Miss America CEO Robert L. Beck, who had suggested it, was fired.{{cite news| url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19990919&slug=2984027 | work=The Seattle Times | first=Nicole | last=Brodeur | title=Here She Is, Miss America: Pageant Faces Reality And Recoils | date=September 19, 1999}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2000-03-01/news/25604798_1_state-pageants-miss-america-organization-robert-renneisen|title=Miss America Finds A Ceo Down By The Boardwalk After 1999's Furor Over Rules Changes, The Former Claridge Official Says He Will Rebuild Bridges To State Pageants.|publisher=}} [[Angela Perez Baraquio]], [[Miss Hawaii]] 2000, was crowned [[Miss America 2001]], thereby becoming the first [[Asian Americans|Asian-American]], the first [[Filipino Americans|Filipino-American]], as well as the first teacher ever to win the pageant.[http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/2000/2001.aspx Miss America 2001] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002114041/http://www.missamerica.org/our-miss-americas/2000/2001.aspx |date=2013-10-02 }} A few years later, the [[Miss America 2005]] pageant held on September 18, 2004, would be the last one televised live on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] (which dropped the pageant after this broadcast, as it "drew a record-low 9.8 million viewers"){{cite news| title=No More Miss America Pageantry for ABC| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A50114-2004Oct20.html| publisher=Washington Post| date=October 21, 2004| first=Lisa| last=de Moraes}} and the last one held in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]] for ten years. [[Miss Alabama]] 2004, [[Deidre Downs]], reigned as Miss America four months longer than usual as the [[Miss America 2006]] pageant was moved to a January broadcast at the [[Las Vegas Strip]]'s [[The AXIS|Theatre for the Performing Arts]] ([[Planet Hollywood Resort & Casino]]).{{cite news |title=CMT Drops Miss America Pageant| publisher=Reuters| author=Kimberly Nordyke| date=March 30, 2007| accessdate=December 15, 2011| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/03/30/us-missamerica-idUSN3042355520070330}}{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CEED9143EF93AA35757C0A9639C8B63&pagewanted=all |title='Fear Factor' Era Poses a Challenge For Miss America| date=April 9, 2005| accessdate= December 15, 2011| work=The New York Times| publisher=NYTimes.com| first=Iver| last=Peterson|registration=yes}} It was also broadcast live on [[Viacom Media Networks|MTV Networks]]' [[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|Country Music Television]]. After two years, the pageant moved to [[TLC (TV network)|TLC (the former Learning Channel)]].{{cite news| title=TLC's the latest to pick Miss America| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/television/tlc-latest-pick-america-article-1.235886| author=Richard Huff| date=August 13, 2007| work=[[Daily News (New York)|New York Daily News]]| publisher=nydailynews.com| accessdate=December 15, 2011}}Shindle, p.182. The [[Miss America 2011]] pageant held on January 15, 2011, showcased [[Miss New York USA|Miss New York]] 2010, [[Claire Buffie]], (the first Miss America contestant to advocate a [[LGBT rights in the United States|gay-rights platform]]){{cite news|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2013/09/14/miss-kansas-bares-tattoos-and-6-other-memorable-miss-america-moments/#ixzz2f40gcyqt |title=Miss Kansas Bares Tattoos and 6 Other Memorable Miss America Moments | TIME.com |publisher=Newsfeed.time.com |date=September 14, 2013 |accessdate=September 22, 2013}}{{cite web|last=Leach |first=Robin |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/vegasdeluxe/2011/jan/14/2011-miss-america-photos-four-contestants-stand-ou/ |title=2011 Miss America photos: Four contestants stand out among field – Las Vegas Sun News |publisher=Lasvegassun.com |date=January 14, 2011 |accessdate=September 22, 2013}} and [[Miss Delaware]] 2010, [[Kayla Martell]], (the first [[alopecia areata|bald]] contestant).{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/06/28/earlyshow/main6626568.shtml|title=Miss Delaware, Bald and Bold|accessdate=June 30, 2010 | work=CBS News | date=June 28, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/miss-america-firsts-nina-davuluri-vanessa-williams-and-more/2013/09/16/b6bbfd58-1d8f-11e3-8685-5021e0c41964_gallery.html#photo=9 |title=Miss America firsts: Nina Davuluri, Vanessa Williams and more |publisher=The Washington Post |accessdate=September 22, 2013}} [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] also resumed broadcasting the pageant with the 2011 competition.{{cite news| title=2011 Miss America Pageant: Ratings increase 47% for ABC telecast| author=Robin Leach| date=January 17, 2011| work=Las Vegas Sun| publisher=lasvegassun.com| url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2011/jan/17/2011-miss-america-pageant-ratings-increase-47-abc-/| accessdate=December 15, 2011}} The [[Miss America 2013]] pageant, held on January 12, 2013, was the last one to take place in Las Vegas. [[Miss New York]] 2012, [[Mallory Hagan]], won the competition but only served for eight months as the pageant moved back to its former broadcast slot in September 2013{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2013/06/12/miss-america-mallory-hagan-in-d-c-making-most-of-short-tenure/|title=Miss America Mallory Hagan in D.C.: Making most of short tenure|first=The Reliable|last=Source|date=12 June 2013|publisher=|via=washingtonpost.com}}{{cite web|url=http://mobile.usnews.com/news/entertainment/articles/2013/03/20/miss-america-to-air-from-atlantic-city-on-sept-15 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412023501/http://mobile.usnews.com/news/entertainment/articles/2013/03/20/miss-america-to-air-from-atlantic-city-on-sept-15 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-04-12 |title=Miss America to air from Atlantic City on Sept. 15 |publisher=www.usnews.com |date=2013-03-20 |accessdate=2013-03-20 }} [[Miss Montana]] 2012, [[Alexis Wineman]], ("America's Choice" winner) was the pageant's first [[Autism|autistic]] contestant.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/miss-america-firsts-nina-davuluri-vanessa-williams-and-more/2013/09/16/b6bbfd58-1d8f-11e3-8685-5021e0c41964_gallery.html#photo=8 |title=Miss America firsts: Nina Davuluri, Vanessa Williams and more |publisher=The Washington Post |accessdate=September 22, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Alexis Wineman, Miss Montana, First Miss America Contestant Diagnosed With Autism|url=http://gma.yahoo.com/blogs/abc-blogs/alexis-wiseman-miss-montana-first-miss-america-contestant-152335413--abc-news-celebrities.html|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=January 12, 2013}} With the [[Miss America 2014]] pageant, held on September 15, 2013, the competition returned to [[Boardwalk Hall]], [[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City]], [[New Jersey]]. [[Miss New York]] ([[Nina Davuluri]]) won the title of Miss America. Davuluri was also the first [[Indian Americans|Indian-American]] and second [[Asian Americans|Asian-American]] to win the crown.{{cite news|last=Cavaliere|first=Victoria|title=Miss New York is first Indian-American to win Miss America|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/09/16/entertainment-us-usa-missamerica-idUSBRE98E0BZ20130916/|accessdate=September 23, 2013|agency=[[Reuters]]|date=September 16, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/Opinion+Nina+Davuluri+matters/8998603/story.html|title=Opinion: Why Nina Davuluri matters|accessdate=|last=Mascarenhas|first=Roland|date=October 4, 2013|publisher= [[The Vancouver Sun]]}} Shortly after her win, however, Davuluri became the target of [[Xenophobia|xenophobic]] and [[Racism|racist]] comments in social media{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/09/16/nina-davuluri-miss-america-religion_n_3934428.html#|title=Nina Davuluri's Miss America 2014 Win Prompts Twitter Backlash Against Indians, Muslims|accessdate=|last= Hafiz|first=Yasmine|date=September 16, 2013|publisher= Huffington Post}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theatlanticwire.com/entertainment/2013/09/first-indian-american-miss-america-has-racists-very-very-confused/69439/|title=The First Indian-American Miss America Has Racists Very, Very Confused|accessdate=|last=Abad-Santos|first=Alex|date=September 16, 2013|publisher= [[The Atlantic]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.elle.com/news/culture/miss-america-bollywood|title=Is Bollywood the New Zumba?|accessdate=|last=Wischhover|first=Cheryl|date=September 26, 2013|publisher= [[ELLE]]}} relating the proximity of [[Aftermath of the September 11 attacks#Backlash and hate crimes|the event date to the 9/11 anniversary]] and to [[anti-Indian sentiment]].{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/ryanhatesthis/a-lot-of-people-are-very-upset-that-an-indian-american-woman|title=A Lot Of People Are Very Upset That An Indian-American Woman Won The Miss America Pageant|accessdate=|last=Broderick|first=Ryan|date=September 16, 2013|publisher= [[BuzzFeed]]}}{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/miss-america-fights-post-pageant-racism-with-a-beauty-queens-poise/2013/09/22/a90590ac-22f8-11e3-966c-9c4293c47ebe_print.html|title=Miss America fights post-pageant racism with a beauty queen's poise|accessdate=|last= Judkis|first=Maura|date=September 22, 2013|publisher=Wall Street Journal}}{{cite news|last=Greenhouse|first=Emily|title=COMBATTING TWITTER HATE WITH TWITTER HATE|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/elements/2013/09/combatting-twitter-hate-with-twitter-hate.html|newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]|date=September 20, 2013}} News agencies cited tweets that misidentified her as Muslim or Arab, associated her with groups such as [[Al-Qaeda]], and questioned why she was chosen over [[Miss Kansas]] 2013, [[Theresa Vail]],{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/opinion/editorial/pigment-of-our-imagination/article5142670.ece|title=Pigment of our imagination|last=Editorial|first=|date=September 19, 2013|publisher= [[The Hindu]]|location=Chennai, India}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2013/09/fox_host_todd_s.php|title=Fox Host Todd Starnes Outraged That Indian-American Nina Davuluri Won Miss America|accessdate=|last=Stuart|first=Tessa|date=September 16, 2013|publisher=[[The Village Voice]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004095427/http://blogs.villagevoice.com/runninscared/2013/09/fox_host_todd_s.php|archivedate=October 4, 2013|df=}} (a soldier who won the "America's Choice" award and was the first contestant to display tattoos during the swimsuit competition).{{cite news|last=Vail|first=Theresa|title=God, Grant Me the Courage to Change the Things I Can|url=http://www.misskansas.org/42-blogs/miss-kansas-2013-blog/275-god-grant-me-the-courage-to-change-the-things-i-can.html|accessdate=|agency=[[Miss Kansas]] Blog|date=August 22, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Linton|first=Caroline|title=Miss Kansas Bares Her Tattoos|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/witw/articles/2013/09/13/miss-kansas-theresa-vail-bares-tattoos-is-in-the-army-national-guard-is-an-expert-marksman.html|accessdate=|agency=''[[The Daily Beast]]''|date=September 14, 2013}} Davuluri said that she was prepared for this backlash because "as Miss New York, I was called a terrorist and very similar remarks",{{cite web|url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/press/atlantic_city/miss-america-promotes-cultural-dialogue-amid-racist-stereotypes/article_979e6e38-1859-5569-8551-78198af53ab1.html|title=Miss America promotes cultural dialogue amid racist stereotypes|accessdate=|last=Khemlani|first=Anjalee|date=November 16, 2013|publisher=[[The Press of Atlantic City]]}}{{cite news|last=Keeler in the Morning|first=|title=[AUDIO] Miss America on Keeler in the Morning|url=http://wibx950.com/audio-miss-america-on-keeler-in-the-morning/|accessdate=October 2, 2013|agency=[[WIBX]]950 AM|date=October 2, 2013}} and Vail denounced the social media backlash, offering her support to Davuluri.{{cite news|url=http://www.misskansas.org/42-blogs/miss-kansas-2013-blog/273-theresa-s-september-blog.html|title=Theresa's September Blog|last=Vail|first=Theresa|date=September 2013|agency=[[Miss Kansas]]|accessdate=}}{{cite news|url=http://www.kansan.com/features/the-story-behind-the-crown-an-interview-with-miss-kansas/article_8a2bf7f1-b3cf-5a61-b13b-ef19a2aae8c9.html|title=The story behind the crown: an interview with Miss Kansas 2013|last=Brady|first=Dani|date=September 29, 2013|agency=''[[University Daily Kansan]]''|accessdate=}} In addition, a torn ACL and MCL forced [[Miss Florida]] 2013, [[Myrrhanda Jones]], to perform her baton routine with a decorated leg brace,{{cite web|date= September 13, 2013| title=Miss Florida, Despite Knee Injury, Wins Miss America Talent Competition|publisher=[[ABC News]]| url=http://abcnews.go.com/blogs/entertainment/2013/09/miss-florida-despite-knee-injury-wins-miss-america-talent-competition/|accessdate=2014-06-12}} while Nicole Kelly ([[Miss Iowa]] 2013) was the first contestant without a forearm to compete in the pageant.{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/style/miss-america-contestant-born-without-forearm-im-just-you-8C11116194|title=Miss America contestant born without forearm: 'I'm just like you'|first=Wayne|last=Parry|publisher=}} [[Amanda Longacre]], who was crowned [[Miss Delaware]] 2014 and was preparing to compete in [[Miss America 2015]], was stripped of the title and the crown{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/dethroned-miss-delaware-files-million-lawsuit/story?id=24602055|title=Dethroned Miss Delaware Amanda Longacre Files $3 Million Lawsuit|date=2014-07-17|publisher=ABC News}}{{cite web|url=http://www.delawareonline.com/story/news/local/2014/07/16/dethroned-beauty-queen-amanda-longacre-sues-miss-delaware-pageant/12752287/|title=Ousted beauty queen sues Miss Del. pageant|last=Brown|first=Robin|date=2014-07-17|publisher=[[The News Journal]]}} because she was deemed to be too old.{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/US/2014/07/17/Miss-Delaware-ousted-for-being-too-old-sues-pageant/5151405616163/|title=Miss Delaware ousted for being too old sues pageant|accessdate=|last=Burns|first=Francis|date=2014-07-17|publisher=United Press International}} Longacre filed a $3 million lawsuit, and Miss America officials later blamed the error on state pageant officials whom, they said, "missed the age discrepancy in Longacre's submitted paperwork." [[Miss New York]] 2014 ([[Kira Kazantsev]]) eventually won the title of [[Miss America 2015]], making New York the first state to produce a winner for three consecutive years.{{cite web|author=Ashleigh Schmitz |url=http://parade.condenast.com/339058/ashleighschmitz/miss-america-2015-5-things-to-know-about-kira-kazantsev/ |title=Miss America 2015: 5 Things to Know About Kira Kazantsev |publisher=Parade.condenast.com |date= |accessdate=2015-05-08}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/kira-kazantsev-marks-third-straight-new-york-victory-america-pageant-article-1.1940607|title=The secrets behind New York's stunning three Miss America wins in a row|accessdate=|last=Friedman|first=Molly|date=September 15, 2014|publisher=New York Daily News}} In September 2014, comedian [[John Oliver]] ran a segment on his show, ''[[Last Week Tonight with John Oliver|Last Week Tonight]]'', that investigated the Miss America Organization's claim that it is "the world's largest provider of scholarships for women."{{cite web|last1=Rupar|first1=Aaron|title=John Oliver's Devastating Takedown of Miss America Has a Local Angle|url=http://www.citypages.com/news/john-olivers-devastating-takedown-of-miss-america-has-a-local-angle-video-6533952|website=City Pages|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=24 September 2014}} Oliver's team, which included four researchers with journalism backgrounds,{{cite web|last1=Blake|first1=Meredith|title=Seven things we learned at breakfast with John Oliver|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/tv/showtracker/la-et-st-john-oliver-last-week-tonight-season-2-20150204-story.html|website=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=4 February 2015}} collected and analyzed the organization's state and federal tax forms to find that the organization's scholarship program only distributes a small fraction of its claimed "$45 million made available annually".{{cite web|last1=Chung|first1=Jen|title=Video: John Oliver Shreds Miss America's Claim To Be "Leading Provider" Of Scholarships To Women|url=http://gothamist.com/2014/09/22/john_oliver_miss_america.php|website=Gothamist|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=22 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150510013519/http://gothamist.com/2014/09/22/john_oliver_miss_america.php|archivedate=10 May 2015|df=}} Oliver said that at the national level, the Miss America Organization and Miss America Foundation together spent only $482,000 in cash scholarships in 2012. Oliver found that at the state level, the [[Miss Alabama]] pageant claimed that it had provided $2,592,000 in scholarships to [[Troy University]] despite not actually distributing any such scholarships.{{cite web|last1=Herman|first1=Barbara|title=John Oliver Takes On Miss America Pageant's ‘Unbelievable’ Scholarship Claims|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/john-oliver-takes-miss-america-pageants-unbelievable-scholarship-claims-1692908|website=International Business Times|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=22 September 2014}} The pageant appeared to multiply the value of a single available scholarship by the number of contestants theoretically eligible for it, while using the term "provided" in a way that did not mean "distributed."{{cite web|title=Last Week Tonight with John Oliver: Miss America Pageant (HBO)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oDPCmmZifE8|website=YouTube|accessdate=28 August 2015|date=21 September 2014}} The Miss America Organization responded by stating that Oliver affirmed that it provides the most scholarships to women and that the $45 million figure was based on all scholarships made available whether or not they are accepted.{{cite web|url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/tv/index.ssf/2014/09/miss_america_john_oliver_scholarships_1.html|title=Miss America Organization responds to John Oliver's segment on pageant|accessdate=|last=Remnick|first=Alex|date=September 22, 2014|publisher=NJ.com}} In February 2015, Sharon Pearce announced that she was stepping down from her role as President of the Miss America Organization. At that time, former CEO Sam Haskell was named Executive Chairman of the Miss America Organization, retained the title of CEO, and assumed all of Pearce's responsibilities.{{cite web |url=http://www.missamerica.org/news/press-releases.aspx?id=833 |title=The Miss America Organization Announces New Leadership Team: Sam Haskell Elevated to Executive Chairman |accessdate=|last= |first= |date=February 27, 2015 |publisher=Miss America Organization |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402092804/http://www.missamerica.org/news/press-releases.aspx?id=833 |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} In addition, [[Miss America 2014]], [[Nina Davuluri]], was appointed one of the new trustees to the Miss America Foundation.{{cite web|url=http://www.missamerica.org/news/press-releases.aspx?id=834 |title=Two Elected to Miss America Foundation Board of Trustees |date=February 27, 2015 |publisher=Miss America Organization |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150302011320/http://www.missamerica.org/news/press-releases.aspx?id=834 |archivedate=March 2, 2015 |df= }} In September 2015, Miss America officials announced that the organization grants $5.5 million in scholarships,{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/13/us-usa-missamerica-idUSKCN0RD0TH20150913|title=Vanessa Williams and the Miss America song return to the pageant|accessdate=|last=Kelley|first=Daniel|date=September 13, 2015|publisher=Reuters}} a number which still includes adding together offers of in-kind tuition waivers from multiple schools when a contestant could accept one at most.{{cite web|url=http://missamericafoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/MAF-Scholarship-Overview-2014.pdf|title=Miss America Organization Scholarship Overview|accessdate=September 11, 2016}} On March 24, 2016, the Miss America Organization announced a contract renewal with [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] to continue carrying the pageant for the next three years to the 2019 edition.{{cite press release|title=THE 96TH MISS AMERICA COMPETITION TO AIR ON SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 11TH AT 9:00 PM ET/PT ON ABC; "The 2017 Miss America Competition" To Broadcast Live From Historic Boardwalk Hall In Atlantic City|publisher=Miss America Organization|date=24 March 2016|url=http://www.missamerica.org/news/press-releases.aspx?id=938|accessdate=28 March 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406155056/http://www.missamerica.org/news/press-releases.aspx?id=938|archivedate=6 April 2016|df=}} In June 2016, [[Erin O'Flaherty]] was crowned [[Miss Missouri]], becoming the first openly lesbian Miss America contestant.{{cite news|last1=CNN|title=First openly gay Miss America contestant|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/01/us/erin-oflaherty-miss-america-gay-contestant/?iid=ob_homepage_deskrecommended_pool|accessdate=5 July 2016|publisher=CNN}} ===2017–present=== In late December 2017, [[HuffPost]] published an article exposing derogatory emails sent and received by CEO Sam Haskell, board members Tammy Haddad and Lynn Weidner, and lead writer Lewis Friedman. The emails, sent between 2014 and 2017, featured instances of expletive name-calling and unprofessional comments. The comments were often sexual or violent in nature and targeted former Miss America winners, notably [[Mallory Hagan]] and [[Katherine Shindle]], both of whom joined 47 other former Miss Americas (including all Miss Americas from 1988 to 2017) in signing a joint open letter calling for the firing or resignation of all involved.{{cite news|last1=HuffPost|title=The Miss America Emails: How The Pageant’s CEO Really Talks About The Winners|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/miss-america-ceo-emails_us_5a3bd266e4b025f99e153fdb|accessdate=22 December 2017|publisher=HuffPost}} On December 22, the Miss America Organization released statements to ''USA Today'', saying that it was made aware of concerns several months prior. They stated that the organization does not "condone the use of inappropriate language" and reported that its investigation had determined that Haskell was under "unreasonable distress resulting from intense attacks on his family from disgruntled stakeholders". The organization also reported that its relationship with Friedman had been terminated. Haskell explained that attacks on his character impaired his judgment when responding to the emails.{{cite news|last1=USA Today|title=Former Miss Americas slam pageant CEO Sam Haskell over offensive emails; pageant responds|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2017/12/22/former-miss-america-mallory-hagan-slams-disgraced-ceo-sam-haskell-following-email-scandal/976037001/|accessdate=22 December 2017|publisher=USAToday}} Miss America's [[board of directors]] also suspended Haskell, who released a statement labeling the HuffPost article "unkind and untrue".{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/miss-america-leadership-resign_us_5a3d3fdce4b025f99e16eca8|title=CEO Suspended After 49 Former Miss Americas Call On Organization's Leaders To Resign|last=Ali|first=Yashar|date=2017-12-22|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-23}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-et-st-miss-america-ceo-suspended-emails-unkind-20171222-story.html|title=Miss America CEO suspended over leaked emails revealed in story he calls 'unkind and untrue'|date=2017-12-22|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-12-23|issn=0458-3035}} Hagan and Shindle criticized the decision to suspend Haskell, rather than fire him, as inadequate.{{Cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/america-winners-fear-pageant-ceo-suspension-article-1.3715705 |title=Ex-Miss America winners worry pageant will end despite CEO Sam Haskell's suspension |last=Dziemianowicz |first=Joe |last2=Dillon |first2=Nancy |date=2017-12-24 |publisher=''[[New York Daily News]]'' |access-date=2017-12-24 |last3=Bitette |first3=Nicole}} The following day, the President of Miss America, Josh Randle; executive chairwoman Lynn Weidner; and Haskell all resigned.{{Cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/exclusive-president-of-miss-america-organization-resigns-amid-email-scandal_us_5a3e8dbce4b0b0e5a7a27c6e|title=Exclusive: President Of Miss America Organization Resigns Amid Scandal|last=Ali|first=Yashar|date=2017-12-23|work=Huffington Post|access-date=2017-12-23}} The scandal prompted the pageant's producer, [[Dick Clark Productions]], to cut ties, and the [[Casino Reinvestment Development Authority]] (CRDA) announced that it was reconsidering its contract with Miss America, with its executive director Chris Howard describing the scandal as "troubling", and both Frank Gilliam, incoming mayor of Atlantic City, and State Senator [[Colin Bell (American politician)|Colin Bell]] called for CRDA to end its relationship with Miss America.{{Cite web |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/new_jersey/top-leader-suspended-at-miss-america-over-offensive-emails-20171222.html |title=Top leader suspended at Miss America over offensive emails |last=Moran |first=Robert |date=2017-12-22 |publisher=''[[The Inquirer]]'' |access-date=2017-12-23}} On December 24, Haddad also resigned.{{Cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2017/12/24/miss-america-scandal-another-leader-steps-down-current-miss-america-speaks-out/979857001/ |title=Miss America scandal: Another leader resigns, former Miss America Mallory Hagan speaks out |last=Mallenbaum |first=Carly |date=2017-12-24 |publisher=''[[USA Today]]'' |access-date=2017-12-24}} In January 2018, [[Gretchen Carlson]], who won the Miss America in 1989, was elected as the new chairwoman of the organization, becoming the first former Miss America to serve as its leader. [[Katherine Shindle]], [[Miss America 1998]], was also appointed to the board alongside fellow Miss America winners, [[Heather French Henry]] ([[Miss America 2000|2000]]) and [[Laura Kaeppeler]] ([[Miss America 2012|2012]]).{{cite news|last = Ali |first = Yashir |date = 2018-01-01 |title = Exclusive: Gretchen Carlson To Serve As Board Chair Of Miss America Organization| publisher = [[HuffPost]] |url= https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/gretchen-carlson-miss-america-board_us_5a4a9307e4b025f99e1cf274?ncid=inblnkushpmg00000009| access-date = 2018-02-01}} This move led to a number of changes. In June 2018, there was an announcement that Miss America contestants would no longer be judged based on their physical appearance. Thus, the national Miss America event would be considered a competition, rather than a beauty pageant, and the titleholders would now be candidates, rather than contestants.{{cite web|first1= Catherine |last1= Thorbecke |first2= Katie |last2= Kindelan |url=https://abcnews.go.com/GMA/Culture/miss-america-scrapping-swimsuit-competition-longer-judge-based/story?id=55638426 |work= ABC News|title=Miss America is scrapping its swimsuit competition, will no longer judge based on physical appearance |date=June 5, 2018}}{{cite web|first=|last=|url=http://missamerica.org/2018/06/05/miss-america-2-0/|work=Miss America Organization|title=Miss America 2.0|date=June 5, 2018|access-date=2018-08-29|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180703072219/http://missamerica.org/2018/06/05/miss-america-2-0/|archive-date=2018-07-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|first=Matthew |last=Haag |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/05/business/miss-america-swimsuit.html |work=[[New York Times]] |title=Miss America Ends Swimsuit Competition, Aiming to Evolve in ‘This Cultural Revolution’ |date=June 5, 2018}}{{cite web|first=Amy S.|last=Rosenberg |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/new_jersey/shore/miss-america-gretchen-carlson-atlantic-city-swimsuit-regina-hopper-20180725.html?mobi=true |work=The Inquirer |title=With six weeks to go, is Miss America 'coming apart at the seams?' |date=July 25, 2018}} The swimsuit competition was replaced with state titleholders participating in a live interactive session with the judges. {{cite web|first1= Doug |last1=Criss |first2= Karma |last2= Hassan |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/06/05/us/miss-america-swimsuit-trnd/index.html |work=[[CNN]] |title=Miss America is scrapping the swimsuit portion from its pageant |date=June 5, 2018}} For the evening gown competition, the contestants chose clothing, "that makes them feel confident, expresses their personal style, and shows how they hope to advance the role of Miss America."{{cite web|first=Megan |last=Garber |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2018/06/miss-america-the-inner-beauty-pageant/562070/ |work=[[The Atlantic]] |title=Miss America 2.0: The Inner Beauty Pageant? |date=June 5, 2018}} In interviews, [[Gretchen Carlson]] emphasized the organization's desire to be more welcoming, "open, transparent, [and] inclusive to women," and to prioritize displaying the talent and scholarship in the contestants.{{cite web|first=Colin |last=Dwyer |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/06/05/617088219/miss-america-drops-its-swimsuit-competition-embracing-whole-new-era |work=[[NPR]] |title=Miss America Says Farewell To Its Swimsuit Competition, Embracing 'Whole New Era' |date=June 5, 2018}} The talent portion was worth 50% of the contestants' preliminary score.{{Cite web|url=https://www.pageantplanet.com/directory/pageant-system/miss-america|title=Miss America - Pageant Planet|website=www.pageantplanet.com|language=en|access-date=2018-07-21}} Additionally, the new board of directors increased the maximum age of titleholders to 25 years old, from 24.{{cite web| first=Daniella |last=Silva |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/future-miss-america-beauty-pageants-question-wake-metoo-n835071 |title=Future of Miss America, beauty pageants in question in the wake of #MeToo |work=NBC News |date=January 7, 2018}} Therefore, contestants cannot be older than 25 years old on December 31 in the calendar year of her state competition. In August 2018, Miss America 2018 [[Cara Mund]] gave an interview to [[The Press of Atlantic City]] in which she stated that it has "been a tough year.”{{cite web |url=https://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/missamerica/miss-america-cara-mund-opens-up-it-s-been-a/article_cacb621b-5057-5e4f-b2e7-8e6fd54308a0.html |title=Miss America Cara Mund opens up: 'It's been a tough year' |accessdate=2018-09-10 |last=Argetsinger |first=Amy |date=2018-08-06 |publisher= [[The Press of Atlantic City]] }} She then wrote an open letter to former Miss Americas a few weeks later, in order to explain her comments. In the letter she states that the current leadership had “silenced me, reduced me, marginalized me, and essentially erased me in my role as Miss America.” She also stated that her "voice is not heard nor wanted by our current leadership …nor do they have any interest in knowing who I am and how my experiences relate to positioning the organization for the future.”{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2018/08/17/no-miss-america-should-be-humiliated-before-giving-up-crown-cara-mund-blasts-pageant-leadership/?utm_term=.63336bf51108 |title=‘No Miss America should be humiliated’: Before giving up crown, Cara Mund blasts pageant leadership |accessdate=2018-09-10 |last=Argetsinger |first=Amy |date=2018-08-17 |publisher= [[Washington Post]] }}{{cite web |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/miss-america-says-leadership-silenced-bullied-her-1135669 |title=In Open Letter, Miss America Cara Mund Says Organization Leadership "Silenced" and Bullied Her |accessdate=2018-09-10 |last=Associated Press |first= |date=2018-08-17 |publisher= Hollywood Reporter }}{{cite web |url=https://bismarcktribune.com/cara-mund-letter/pdf_bdb98d8a-646e-54e8-830a-8905366ec2cf.html |title=‘Cara Mund letter |accessdate=2018-09-10 |last=Mund |first=Cara |date=2018-08-17 |publisher= [[The Bismarck Tribune]] }} Chairwoman [[Gretchen Carlson]] has denied Mund's claims.{{cite web |url=https://people.com/tv/gretchen-carlson-miss-america-cara-mund-bullied/ |title=Gretchen Carlson Responds to Miss America Cara Mund's Claims That She Was 'Bullied' |accessdate=2018-09-10 |last=McNiece |first=Mia |date=2018-08-17 |publisher= [[People Magazine]] }} However, at the time the Miss America 2019 competition began, 46 of 51 state organizations (as well as 23 former Miss America winners) had signed a petition calling for the resignation of Carlson and CEO, Regina Hopper, from the Miss America Organization.{{cite web|first=|last= |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2018/09/06/miss-america-2019-swimsuit-less-competition-enters-day-2-prelims/1212272002/|title=Swimsuit-less Miss America competition enters Day 2 of prelims: 'Swimsuit is behind us' |work= USATODAY |date=September 6, 2018}} The states who had not signed were Arkansas, Kentucky, Minnesota, Nevada, and Vermont. On September 5, 2018, Fox Rothschild LLP, a law firm based in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], filed a breach-of-contract suit against the Miss America Organization for failing to pay nearly $100,000 for legal services.{{cite web| first=Jim |last=Walsh |url=https://www.courierpostonline.com/story/news/local/south-jersey/2018/09/06/lawsuit-claims-miss-america-pageant-owes-fox-rothschild/1214428002/ |title=Lawsuit claims Miss America Organization didn't pay its bill |work=Cherry Hill Courier-Post|date=September 6, 2018}} ==Winners== [[File:Cara Mund 2018.jpg|140px|thumb|[[Miss America 2018]], [[Cara Mund]]]] === Recent titleholders === {{Main|List of Miss America titleholders}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Title year ! Name ! State represented |- | align="center"| [[Miss America 2019|2019]] | align="center"| [[Nia Franklin]]{{cite web|first=Chloe |last=Melas |title=Miss America 2019 is Nia Franklin |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/09/09/entertainment/miss-america-winner-nia-franklin/index.html |work=[[CNN]] |date=September 10, 2018}} | align="center"| {{flagicon|New York}} [[Miss New York|New Georgia is crowned Miss America 2016 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/2015/09/13/miss-georgia--crowned-miss-america-2016/72237830/ |date=September 14, 2015}} | align="center"| revision.comment: /* About the Team */HTTP→HTTPS, per [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/Bender the Bot 8|BRFA 8]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Mizzou Hydrogen Car Team''' designs, builds and competes with an Urban Concept [[Fuel cell vehicle|hydrogen fuel cell vehicle]] run by students at the [[University of Missouri]] in [[Columbia, Missouri]]. They recently competed with their vehicle named "Tigergen III" in the 2013 [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] [[Eco-marathon|Eco-Marathon]]. At the competition they achieved 8.8 mi/kWh which placed them 3rd in the UrbanConcept Hydrogen category.<ref>Releases, News and Media. [http://www.shell.com/home/content/ecomarathon/americas/media/event_highlights/2011/04172011_final.html "Winners for Shell Eco-marathon Americas 2011"], "Shell", April 17, 2011, accessed April 20, 2011.</ref> The team also won an off-track award for "Best Team Spirit"
==About the Team== [[File:Tigergen II team photo.jpg|thumb|right|Tigergen II team photo]] [[File:Suntiger6 team photo.jpg|thumb|left|Suntiger 6 team photo]]
The team, located on the campus of the University of Missouri and run entirely by students, seeks to promote awareness of alternative fuels, develop technology, and allow members to gain practical experience through constructing a hydrogen vehicle. Advised by Professor Richard Whelove of the Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering Department, as well as Richard Wallace of the Electrical Engineering Department, the team was formerly known as the Mizzou Solar Car Team. The team switched over to hydrogen after 6 generations of solar cars. The team remains advised by Richard Whelove, alongside Michael Devaney of the Electrical Engineering Department.<ref>Fisher, Paul. [https://www.wired.com/autopia/2008/07/racing-to-canad/ "Racing to Canada in a Hydrogen Car"], "Wired", July 11, 2008, accessed March 23, 2011.</ref> The team's first venture into hydrogen powered vehicles was with Tigergen I which ran on two 1.2 kW [[Ballard Power Systems|Ballard]] fuel cells and exhibitioned in the [[North American Solar Challenge]] as a demonstration vehicle.<ref>Myers, Justin. [http://www.columbiamissourian.com/stories/2008/07/02/mu-students-set-race-hydrogen-car/ "MU students set to race hydrogen car"], "Missourian", July 2, 2008, accessed March 23, 2011.</ref> The team's second vehicle, Tigergen II, operated on a single 1.2 kW Ballard fuel cell and competed in the Urban Concept category of the Shell Eco Marathon, winning first place in the hydrogen category and fourth place overall in 2011. The team's current vehicle, Tigergen III, operates on two 1 kW Horizon fuel cells and competed Shell Eco Marathon Americas competition, placing third in the hydrogen UrbanConcept category.
==Current Technology== The body and chassis of Tigergen III is integrated as a partial-load bearing system in a partial-[[monocoque]] design. This construction technique saves weight without compromising the structural integrity of the vehicle. To further reduce weight, Tigergen III's partial monocoque structure is composed entirely of composite materials. Carbon fiber and nomex material is used extensively throughout the car. Tigergen III uses Horizon hydrogen fuels cell to convert energy from hydrogen gas into electricity which is then used to power the vehicle's electric motor. Safety is a priority in Tigergen III. The driver is secured with a five-point racing safety harness along with the driver being separated from all components of the fuel system by a fire-resistant bulkhead and easy access to a fire extinguisher. Tigergen III competed in the 2012 and 2013 Shell Eco-Marathons.
==Objectives of the Race== The purpose of the [http://www.shell.com/home/content/ecomarathon/americas/ Shell Eco Marathon] race is to drive as far as possible on the least amount of fuel. The competition is based on efficiency rather than speed and awards are given to teams that use the least amount of fuel while driving on a 6-mile circuit. The Urban Concept category subjects vehicles to constraints that resemble those of a consumer vehicle such as brake lights, luggage space, and four wheels along with stop-and-go driving. The next competition takes place March 2012 at Discovery Green in Houston, TX.
==Race Results==
===2010 Shell Eco Marathon=== {| class="wikitable" align="right" |+ '''2011 Race Results''' ! Run ! mi/kWh ! MPG ! Driver |- | 1 | 10.76 | 372 | Jennifer Claybrooks |- | 2 | 12.87 | 445 | Jennifer Claybrooks |- | 3 | 12.83 | 443 | Jennifer Claybrooks |- | 4 | 13.19 | 456 | Jennifer Claybrooks |- | 5 | style="background:yellow;"|13.79 | style="background:yellow;"|476 | Jennifer Claybrooks |- | 6 | 12.87 | 445 | Andy McMullen |}
The team competed for the first time with their vehicle named "Tigergen II" in the [[Royal Dutch Shell|Shell]] [[Eco-marathon|Eco-Marathon]] although it did not finish the race due to technical difficulties.<ref>Simonds, Ethan. [http://www.themaneater.com/stories/2010/4/6/mu-hydrogen-car-shows-potential-houston-race/ "MU hydrogen car shows potential in Houston race"], "The Maneater", April 6, 2010, accessed March 23, 2011.</ref> The team was awarded a trophy and monetary prize for the "Perseverance in the Face of Adversity" as a result of the hard work they did to get the car working at the race.
===2011 Shell Eco Marathon=== In 2011 the team competed for the second time with Tigergen II with much greater success than before. Tigergen II completed all six runs to receive six qualifying results. Run 2 experienced a technical problem but the fuel cell was rebooted and the run was completed. Of the six runs the highest efficiency obtained was on run "5" with 13.79 mi/kWh or 476 MPG. The team was awarded with First Prize for the Hydrogen Category in the Urban Concept Division. The team was also awarded a trophy and monetary prize for "Best Team Spirit"
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://mizzouhydrogen.org/ Mizzou Hydrogen Car Team Homepage] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/MizzouHydrogen Videos of hydrogen vehicles in action] * [http://www.connectmidmissouri.com/news/story.aspx?id=591297 Local CBS news broadcast of team] * [http://www.shell.com/home/content/ecomarathon Shell Eco-marathon official website] * [https://www.youtube.com/user/MizzouHydrogen Official YouTube channel]

revision.text:
A '''national postgraduate representative body''' exists in many countries representing [[postgraduate]] students/researchers undertaking their [[doctorate]] ([[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]]) or [[Postdoctoral researcher|postdoctoral research]]. Some have a broader remit to represent all postgraduates, including those taking [[Master's degree]]s. A few countries have no specific body but are represented by a national body representing all students, including [[undergraduates]].
In Europe many of the national organisations have come together under the federation [[Eurodoc]].

'''Numa S. Trivas''' (1899–17 April 1942) was an art historian and collector who became a curator of art at the [[E. B. Crocker Art Gallery]]. He was born in [[Mykolaiv|Nicolaef]], Russia and studied at the Institute of Art History in [[Saint Petersburg]], finishing his studies at the [[Ecole du Louvre]] in Paris and the [[University of Berlin]]. He was active from 1926 in Amsterdam, where he worked for the Rothmann gallery, and emigrated before World War II to New York City in 1939, settling in [[Sacramento]], California.
==Works== *Three Centuries of Landscape Drawing: Exhibition Held in August Through October 1940 *The Paintings of [[Frans Hals]], 1941 *A Pioneering Collection: Master Drawings from the Crocker, 1940 *Two Formulas by Liotard, 1941 *Les portraits de [[J.-E. Liotard]] par lui-mème, 1936
==References== *[[c:Frans Hals catalog raisonné, 1941|The Paintings of Frans Hals: Complete Edition]] by Numa S. Trivas, London, George Allen & Unwin, 1941 *[https://archive.org/stream/whoswhoincalifor194243flet#page/918/mode/2up Numa S. Trivas] in [[Who's Who]] in California, 1942-1943
