[[File:Лукашев Володимир Анатолійович 02.JPG|300px|thumb|Volodymyr Lukashev]] '''Volodymyr Lukashev''' (born May 7, 1936) - Ukrainian opera director, theatrical figure, teacher. [[People's Artist of Ukraine]], winner of international awards, Professor.
In years 1973-1988 - director of [[Kharkiv opera]]. In years 1963-1989 professor of [[Kharkiv National Kotlyarevsky University of Arts]]
Since 1996 - director of [[National Philharmonic of Ukraine]]. Since 1999 - professor of [[Kiev Conservatory]].
== Links == * [http://logos-ukraine.com.ua/project/index.php?project=piued3&id=1313 Почесні імена України] * [http://composer.ucoz.ua/publ/muzikanti_i_muzichni_dijachi/lukashev_volodimir_anatolijovich/36-1-0-253 Лукашев, Володимир Анатолійович] // Українська музична енциклопедія, Т.3 — Ін-т мистецтвознавства, фольклористики та етнології ім. М. Т. Рильського НАН України. 2011
[[Category:Drama teachers]] [[Category:Ukrainian theatre directors]] [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:Living people]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Lukashev}}

{{Use British English|date=September 2018}} {{Other uses|Whipping boy (disambiguation)}} [[File:Whipping-boy.jpg|thumb|"Edward VI and his Whipping Boy" by Walter Sydney Stacey from his 1882 oil painting.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/magazineofart06londuoft#page/n153/mode/1up ''The magazine of art'' vol.6 p.133]</ref>]] A '''whipping boy''' or girl are children who are in slavery and suffer corporal punishment on behalf of their young master when the latter did something wrong. As both grew up and spend quite a lot of time together, a friendship or affectionate tie often developed between the young slave child and the young master. The slave boy or girl had to undergo the physical punishment and the young master had to watch, thus undergoing an emotional punishment instead of a physical which was / is often seen as too cruel to inflict on one's own children or children of one's own [[caste]].
The winner of the [[Prix des droits de l'homme des Nations unies]] 2013 [[Biram Dah Abeid]] - who was raised himself as a child slave in [[Mauritania]] - testifies of this practise of child [https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Souffre-douleur enfant souffre-douleur] in [[Mauritania]]. In the slavery caste it is customary that when boys reach the age of circumcision, they can choose a slave boy who will grow up with his young master. Because they spend a lot of time together, it happens that a certain bond of friendship or appreciation settles between the young master and his slave. To punish the young master, there is a custom of subjecting punishments e.g. floggings to the young slave instead of this master who is obliged to watch his friend undergoing the flogging, thus inflicting the master this way emotional suffering, but not the physical suffering which is too cruel according to local custom to be born by their own children.
A '''whipping boy''' or girl was, supposedly, a child educated alongside a [[prince]]/[[princes]] (or boy [[monarch]]) in [[early modern Europe]], who received [[corporal punishment]] for the prince's transgressions in his presence. The prince was not punished himself because his royal status exceeded that of his tutor; seeing a friend punished would provide an equivalent motivation not to repeat the offence. An archaic proverb which captures a similar idea is "to beat a dog before a lion".<ref>Wesselski 1928, p.127 [German equivalent: "den Hund vor dem Löwen schlagen"]; {{cite book |last=Chaucer |first=Geoffrey |editor=Donald C. Baker |title=The Squire's Tale |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Vos-G17FaEC&pg=PA215 |accessdate=14 January 2018 |series=Variorum Edition of the works of Chaucer |volume=Part 2 : The Canterbury Tales ; Volume 12 |year=1990 |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |isbn=9780806121543 |pages=215–216, fn. 490–91 }}</ref> [[Whipping]] was a common punishment of tutors at that time. There is little contemporary evidence for the existence of whipping boys, and evidence that some princes were indeed whipped by their tutors, although [[Nicholas Orme]] suggests that nobles might have been beaten less often than other pupils.<ref>Orme 2017 pp.33–35</ref> Some historians regard whipping boys as entirely mythical; others suggest they applied only in the case of a boy king, protected by [[divine right of kings|divine right]], and not to mere princes.<ref name="Ridley2013">{{cite book|last=Ridley|first=Jasper|title=A Brief History of the Tudor Age|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3yKfBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT137|accessdate=5 January 2018|date=2013-02-07|publisher=Little, Brown Book Group|isbn=9781472107954|page=137}}</ref>
In [[Renaissance humanism]], [[Erasmus]]' treatises "[[The Education of a Christian Prince]]" (1516) and "Declamatio de pueris statim ac liberaliter instituendis" (1530) mention the inappropriateness of physical chastisement of princes, but do not mention proxy punishment.<ref>Bushnell 1996 p.50</ref> [[Hartley Coleridge]] wrote in 1852, "to be flogged by proxy was the exclusive privilege of royal blood. ... It was much coveted for the children of the poorer [[gentry]], as the first step in the ladder of preferment."<ref name="ColeridgeColeridge1852">{{cite book|last1=Coleridge|first1=Hartley|last2=Coleridge|first2=Derwent|last3=Coleridge|first3=Samuel Taylor|title=Lives of northern worthies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3EcEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA172|accessdate=9 January 2018|year=1852|publisher=Edward Moxon|page=172, fn}}</ref> [[John Gough Nichols]] wrote in 1857, "the whole matter is somewhat legendary, and though certain vicarious or rather minatory punishments may have been occasionally adopted, it does not seem likely that any one individual among the King's schoolfellows should have been uniformly selected, whether he were in fault or not, as the victim or scape-goat of the royal misdemeanours".<ref name="Nichols1857">{{cite book|last=Nichols|first=John Gough |authorlink=John Gough Nichols|title=Literary Remains of King Edward the Sixth: Edited from His Autograph Manuscripts, with Historical Notes and a Biographical Memoir|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=7TUJAAAAQAAJ&pg=PR69|accessdate=18 January 2018|year=1857|publisher=J. B. Nichols|pages=lxx–lxxiii|chapter=Biographical Memoir of King Edward the Sixth}}</ref> In current English, a "whipping boy" is a [[metaphor]] which may have a similar meaning to [[scapegoat]], [[fall guy]], or [[sacrificial lamb]]; alternatively it may mean a perennial loser or a victim of group bullying.
==Putative historical examples== Young royals alleged to have had whipping boys include: * [[Conrad IV of Germany|Conrad, King of Jerusalem and later of Italy]] (1228–1254) had twelve companions beaten in his stead by his tutors, according to the ''{{ill|Cento Novelle Antiche|it|Novellino}}'' (c.1300), so that "King Conrad took great heed not to act wrongly, for of pity them".<ref>Wesselski 1928 pp.126–127</ref><ref>{{cite book |chapter=XLVIII: Here it is told of King Conrad, father of Conradin |translator-last=Storer |translator-first=Edward |translator-link=Edward Storer |title=Il novellino, the Hundred old tales |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/ilnovellinohundr00stor#page/119 |registration=Y |series=Broadway Translations |year=1925 |publisher=E.P. Dutton & Co |location=New York |pages=119–120}}</ref> [[Alessandro d'Ancona]] sees an antecedent of the Conrad ''novella'' in [[Phaedrus (fabulist)|Phaedrus]]' fable "The Bullock and the Old Ox".<ref>{{cite book |last=d'Ancona |first=Alessandro |title=Studj di critica e storia letteraria |url=https://archive.org/stream/studjdicriticae00ancogoog#page/n333 |year=1880 |publisher=N. Zanichelli |location=Bologna |language=Italian |pages=318–319}}; {{cite book|author1=Babrius|author2=Phaedrus |translator-first=Ben Edwin |translator-last=Perry |title=Fables|chapterurl=https://www.loebclassics.com/view/phaedrus-fables/1965/pb_LCL436.389.xml|series=[[Loeb Classical Library]]|volume=436|year=1965|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|language=English and Latin|pages=388–389|chapter=Phaedrus No. 12 : The Bullock and the Old Ox}} {{cite web|url=http://mythfolklore.net/aesopica/walter/50.htm |title=Fable 50. De patre et filio. (Walter of England - Nevelet) |work=Aesopica |language=Latin |accessdate=16 January 2018}}; {{cite book|last1=McKenzie|first1=Kenneth|last2=Oldfather|first2=William Abbott|title=Ysopet-Avionnet : the Latin and French texts |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/ysopetavionnetla00aeso#page/204/mode/2up |date=1919 |publisher=University of Illinois |location=Urbana |pages=10, 46, 204–205 |chapter=67. D'un père et d'un enfant. }}</ref> * [[Henry FitzRoy, 1st Duke of Richmond and Somerset]] (1519–1536), whose tutor [[Richard Croke]] complained in 1527 that Richmond's usher, [[George Cotton (courtier)|George Cotton]], was undermining Croke's authority; among the charges were withdrawing "those boys whose punishment it was necessary to deter his princely pupil from the repetition of his faults", and claiming it was unseemly for Croke to whip them in Richmond's presence.<ref name="Nichols1857"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Nichols|first=John Gough|title=Inventories of the wardrobes, plate, chapel stuff, etc. of Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Richmond, and of the wardrobe stuff at Baynard's Castle of Katharine, Princess Dowager |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/inventoriesofwar00richrich#page/n38/|series=Camden Miscellany|volume=Vol.3 No.4|date=1855 |publisher=Camden Society|location=London|pages=xxxvii–xlv|chapter=Biographical Memoir of Henry Fitzroy, Duke of Richmond}}</ref> * [[Edward VI of England]] (1537–1553) to whose court [[Barnaby Fitzpatrick, 2nd Baron Upper Ossory|Barnaby Fitzpatrick, later 2nd Baron Upper Ossory]] (c.1535–1581) was sent as a hostage by his father [[Barnaby Fitzpatrick, 1st Baron Upper Ossory|the 1st baron]]. [[Thomas Fuller]]'s ''Church-History of Britain'' (1655) calls Fitzpatrick Edward's "proxy for correction". [[John Guy (historian)|John Guy]] calls this a myth, since their tutor [[Richard Cox (bishop)|Richard Cox]] wrote of beating Edward with his staff.<ref name="Guy2013">{{cite book|last=Guy|first=John|title=The Children of Henry VIII|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=ebvmoj_MjY4C&pg=PT94|accessdate=4 January 2018|date=2013-04-25|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=9780191655944|page=94|chapter=Ruling from the Grave}}</ref> [[Konrad Heresbach]] in ''De Educandis Erudiendisque Principum Liberis'' (1592) recounted that he was told in London in 1547 that, when the young king uttered profanities learnt from an (unnamed) playmate, the friend was whipped in his presence and Edward warned that he deserved similar punishment.<ref>{{cite book |chapter=Cap. 19. De Continentia |chapterurl=https://www2.uni-mannheim.de/mateo/camenahist/heresbach1/jpg/s117.html |title=De Educandis Erudiendisque Principum Liberis |last=Heresbach |first=Conrad |year=1592 |publisher=Frankfurt |pages=117–118 |language=Latin |accessdate=11 January 2018}}; Cited and translated in Bushnell 1996 p.54</ref> * The future [[Frederick IV of Liegnitz]] (1552–96), for whom {{ill|Hans von Schweinichen|de}} (1552–1616) was described in 1856 as the {{lang|de|"Prügeljunge"}} by [[Gustav Freytag]],<ref>{{cite journal |title=Bilder aus der deutschen Vergangenheit : die Schlesier und ihr toller Herzog Heinrich. 2. |journal=Die Grenzboten : Zeitschrift für Politik, Literatur und Kunst |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jgwnAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA116 |year=1856 |publisher=Friedrich Ludwig Herbig|location=Leipzig |volume=15 |number=II Semester, IV Band |language=German |pages=106–121 : 116 |quote=Als Knabe Page des eingesperrten Herzog Friedrich des Vaters und Prügeljunge Friedrich des Sohns, hatte er das wilde Treiben des Liegnitzer Fürstenhofs schon früh aus dem Grunde kennen gelernt und sich in alle Mysterien desselben eingelebt.}}</ref> popularising the concept in Germany.<ref name="Wesselski126"/> Freytag's claim is not supported by other accounts of Schweinichen.<ref name="Wesselski126"/> * The future [[Charles I of England]] (1600–49), to whom [[William Murray, 1st Earl of Dysart|William Murray, later 1st Earl of Dysart]] (c.1600–55) was "[[page (servant)|page]] and whipping–boy" according to [[Gilbert Burnet]]'s ''History of my own time'' (1723).<ref>{{cite book|last=Burnet|first=Gilbert|title=Bishop Burnet's history of his own time : from the restoration of King Charles the second to the treaty of peace at Utrecht, in the reign of Queen Anne|url=https://archive.org/stream/historyofowntime01burnuoft#page/39|edition=New|volume=1|year=1850|publisher=W.S. Orr |orig-year=1723 |location=London |pages=39 |quote=Mr. Murray, of the bed–chamber, had been page and whipping–boy to king Charles the First ; and had great credit with him, not only in procuring private favours, but in all his counsels. }}</ref><ref name="Beddard">{{cite journal |journal=[[History Today]] |first=Robert |last=Beddard |title=Ham House |url=http://www.historytoday.com/robert-beddard/ham-house |date=January 1995 |volume=45 |issue=1}}</ref><ref name="Pritchard">{{cite book |first=Evelyn |last=Pritchard |title=Ham House and its owners through five centuries 1610-2006 |year=2007 |publisher=Richmond Local History Society |isbn=9781955071727}}</ref><ref name="Wesselski126">Wesselski 1928 p.126</ref> William's uncle [[Thomas Murray (provost of Eton)|Thomas Murray]] tutored both boys.<ref name="GordonLawton2003">{{cite book|last1=Gordon|first1=Peter|last2=Lawton|first2=Denis|title=Royal Education: Past, Present, and Future|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SRye55LCNFYC&pg=PA58|accessdate=12 January 2018|year=2003|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=9780714683867|page=58}}</ref> As king, Charles appointed William [[Groom of the Bedchamber]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1604-1629/member/murray-william-1600-1655 |title=Murray, William (c.1600–1655), of St. Martin-in-the-Fields, Westminster and Ham, Surr. |work=The History of Parliament |volume=The House of Commons 1604-1629 |editor1-first=Andrew |editor1-last=Thrush |editor2-first=John P. |editor2-last=Ferris |date=2010 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |last=Hunneyball |first=Paul |accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref> * The young [[Louis XV of France]] (1710–1774) was supplied by his governess [[Madame de Ventadour]] with playmates of his own age, including a Versailles cobbler's son nicknamed {{lang|fr|le hussard}} ("the [[hussar]]") from a costume he wore.<ref>{{cite book|last=Petitfils|first=Jean-Christian|title=Louis XV|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=fHgdBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT52|accessdate=15 January 2018|date=6 November 2014 |publisher=edi8|isbn=9782262050078|page=52|chapter=La première formation du roi}}; {{cite book|last=Antoine|first=Michel|title=Louis XV|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=zOevvujOlJEC&pg=PT29|accessdate=15 January 2018|date=11 October 1989|publisher=Fayard|language=French|isbn=9782213647814|page=29|chapter=Caprices et chagrins}}</ref> [[Marie Anne de Vichy-Chamrond, marquise du Deffand|Marie, marquise du Deffand]] wrote in 1769 that this boy would be punished in the king's stead, whence the victim of any bully was colloquially called their ''hussard''.<ref name="Deffand1813">{{cite book|last=Deffand|first=Marie Du|title=Lettres de la marquise du Deffand à Horace Walpole, depuis comte d'Orford, écrites dans les années 1766 à 1780 ; auquelles sont jointes des lettres de madame Du Deffand à Voltaire, écrites dans les années 1775: publiées d'après les originaux déposés à Strawberry-Hill|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=ATwEhlmBa-8C&pg=PA348|accessdate=15 January 2018|volume=Vol.1|year=1813|publisher=Treustel et Wurtz|location=Paris|language=French|page=348|chapter=Letter 73: 2 November 1769 |quote=c'est son ''hussard''; je ne sais pas si vous entendez cela; le roi dans son enfance avait un petit hussard qu'on fouettait quand le roi n'avait pas bien dit sa leçon.}}; {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/leducdelauzunet00mauggoog#page/n306 |title=Le duc de Lauzun et la cour intime de Louis XV |last=Maugras |first=Gaston |year=1907 |publisher=Plon |page=286 |language=French |accessdate=15 January 2018 |location=Paris}}</ref> {{ill|Jacques-Antoine Dulaure|fr}} in 1825 called the method "strange", "rather barbarous", and "iniquitous", and said Louis continued to neglect his studies regardless.<ref name="Dulaure1825">{{cite book|last=Dulaure|first=Jacques-Antoine|title=Histoire civile, physique et morale de Paris|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=rRgCAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA395|accessdate=15 January 2018|volume=Vol.7|year=1825|publisher=Baudouin Frères|language=French|page=395–396, fn (1) |chapter=Paris sous Louis XV |edition=3rd}}</ref> * [[Spanish royal family|Spanish royal princes]] had Francisco Alphonso de la Torre, an illegitimate son of [[Manuel Godoy]], as proxy to receive "either slaps or the whip", according to the 1898 memoirs of [[François Certain de Canrobert]], who served in the [[French Army]] under de la Torre in 1842 [[French conquest of Algeria|in Algeria]] and ascribed his irascibility to this education.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bapst|first=Germain |title=Le Maréchal Canrobert, souvenirs d'un siècle |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/lemarchalcanro01bapsuoft#page/389/mode/1up|series=389|volume=Vol.1|date=1909 |publisher=Plon |location=Paris|language=French |chapter=VI : Le Général Bugeaud et la Conquête du Dahra }}</ref> *{{anchor|haha juse}}<!-- [[haha juse]] and others redirect here -->[[Royal and noble ranks of the Qing dynasty#Imperial clan|Chinese imperial princes]] of the [[Qing Dynasty]] (1644–1912) had [[Identity in the Eight Banners|banner]] attendants denoted by the [[Manchu language|Manchu]] term {{lang|mnc|haha juse}} ([[Transcription into Chinese characters|Chinese transcription]] {{lang|zh|哈哈珠子}}); at first this meant youths educated alongside the prince, and later his special "reading partner" and bodyguard.<ref name="Li2016">{{cite journal|last=Li|first=Wenyi|date=15 February 2016|title=Some Explanations of the 'Haha Juse' in the Qing Dynasty|journal=The Qing History Journal|volume=0|issue=1|pages=48–62|issn=1002-8587|url=http://qsyj.iqh.net.cn/EN/abstract/abstract2223.shtml|language=Chinese}}</ref> These were influential in the [[Kangxi Emperor|Kangxi]] reign (1661–1722) but subsequently lost status.<ref name="Li2016" /> In 1876, the ''[[North-China Herald]]'' commented on the announcement in the ''[[Peking Gazette]]'' of the start of the education of the five-year-old [[Guangxu Emperor]]: "The next appointment to be made (though not [[Government gazette|gazette]]d) will probably be that of the child who, according to the Manchu Imperial custom, shares his Majesty's studies under the name of ''{{lang|zh|{{’}}ha{{’}}hachutsze}}'', in the capacity of a {{lang|fr|souffre-douleur}} or "whipping-boy." Whenever the [[Son of Heaven]] is naughty or inattentive, the ''{{lang|zh|{{’}}ha{{’}}hachutsze}}'' is beaten or disgraced".<ref>{{cite book|title=Translations of the "Peking Gazette" 1876, reprinted from the "North China Herald"|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.b3001902;view=1up;seq=28 |date=April 1877|page=4}}</ref>
An adult example often included in discussions of whipping boys is provided by the French Catholic prelates [[Arnaud d'Ossat]] (1537–1604) and [[Jacques Davy Duperron]] (1556–1618), who were symbolically whipped by [[Pope Clement VIII]] in 1593 in proxy expiation on behalf of [[Henry IV of France]] (1553–1610), who had renounced Protestantism.<ref>Mentioned in: Thiselton Dyer 1903 p.307; {{cite book|last1=Butler|first1=Samuel |authorlink1=Samuel Butler (poet)|last2=Grey|first2=Zachary|authorlink2=Zachary Grey|title=Hudibras|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OkpfuQcyTAEC&pg=PA120|volume=1|year=1819|publisher=Charles & Henry Baldwyn|location=London|page=120, fn 2}}; [https://archive.org/stream/magazineofart06londuoft#page/171 ''The magazine of art'' vol.6 pp.170–171]; {{cite book |date=1898 |url=http://www.bartleby.com/81/17407.html |location=Philadelphia |title=Whipping Boy| last=Brewer |first=E. Cobham |authorlink=E. Cobham Brewer |work=Dictionary of Phrase & Fable |publisher=Henry Altemus |accessdate=12 January 2018}}</ref>
==In later literature== [[Samuel Rowley]]'s 1604 play ''[[When You See Me You Know Me]]'' depicts the childhood of the future Edward VI. When he skips class to play [[real tennis|tennis]], Edward "Ned" Browne is sent to the chapel to be whipped by the master of children. [[Thomas Cranmer|Cranmer]] says, "Since he was whipped thus for the prince's faults. / His grace hath got more knowledge in a month. / Than he attained in a year before, / For still the fearful boy, to save his breech, / Doth hourly haunt him, wheresoe'er he goes." The prince persuades king [[Henry VIII]] to knight Ned: "the poor gentleman was pitifully wounded in the back parts, as may appear by the scar, if his knightship would but untruss there". Ned hopes the tutors will refrain from whipping a knight, to which the [[jester|fool]] retorts, "If they do, he shall make thee a [[Peerage of England|lord]], and then they dare not." This work may have helped the idea of a whipping boy to take root.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rowley |first=Samuel|editor-last=Elze |editor-first=Karl|title=When you see me, you know me. A chronicle-history |url=https://archive.org/stream/cu31924013134113#page/n77 |date=1874 |publisher=E. Barth|location=Dessau|pages=46–50}}; {{cite book|last=Mark H.|first=Lawhorn|editor-first=Konrad |editor-last=Eisenbichler |title=The Premodern Teenager: Youth in Society, 1150-1650|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=2NQnbW8CW54C&pg=PA131|accessdate=4 January 2018|year=2002|publisher=Centre for Reformation and Renaissance Studies, Victoria University |location=Toronto|isbn=9780772720184|pages=131–150|chapter=Taking Pains for the Prince: age, Patronage, and Penal Surrogacy in Samuel Rowley's When You See Me, You Know Me}}</ref>
[[John Donne]] alluded to proxy whipping in a [[sermon]] he preached in 1628: "Sometimes, when the children of great persons offend at school, another person is whipped for them, and that affects them, and works upon a good nature; but if that person should take physic for them in a sickness, it would do them no good: God's corrections upon others may work by way of example upon thee; but because thou art sick for physic, take it thyself."<ref name="Donne2013">{{cite book|last1=Donne|first1=John|editor-last=Colclough |editor-first=David |editorlink=Dave Colclough|title=The Oxford Edition of the Sermons of John Donne|chapter=Commentaries: Sermon 7 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=hVUQAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA367|accessdate=9 January 2018|volume=3: Sermons Preached at the Court of Charles I|date=November 2013 |publisher=OUP |location=Oxford|isbn=9780199565481 |page=367, lines 802–4}}</ref> The earliest attestation of the word "whipping boy" in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' is from a 1647 [[Bible commentary]] by [[John Trapp]] on {{Bible verse|1 Tim|5:20|KJV}}: "Those Presbyters that sin publikely ... and those who were convicted by two or three witnesses ... : Rebuke before all, yet not as if they were whipping boyes".<ref>{{cite book |title=A New English Dictionary on Historical Principles |volume=vol.X pt.II |date=17 May 1923 |chapterurl=https://archive.org/stream/newenglishdictio102murruoft#page/n752/mode/1up |chapter=sv ''whipping-boy'' |page=Wh–Worling p.57 col.3 |nopp=Y |accessdate=12 January 2018}}; the 1647 citation is reprinted in {{cite book|last=Trapp|first=John|title=A Commentary Or Exposition Upon All the Books of the New Testament|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=M0g7AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA836|accessdate=10 January 2018 |year=1656|publisher=R.W. for Nath. Ekins |page=836 |chapter=1 Timothy |location=London }}</ref>
In Book V of ''[[Gil Blas]]'' (1715) by [[Alain-René Lesage]], when the Marquis of Leganez forbids his son's tutors from beating him, Don Raphael is flogged in his stead: "a most ingenious device, by which to keep this troublesome young lordling in awe, without trenching on his foolish father's injunctions".<ref>{{cite book|last=Lesage|first=Alain-René |translator-link=Tobias Smollett |translator-last=Smollett|translator-first=Tobias|editor-last=Fullerton |editor-link=William Morton Fullerton |editor-first=William Morton |title=Gil Blas|chapterurl=https://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/l/lesage/alain-rene/gil-blas/book5.1.html|year=1913|publisher=George Routledge & Sons|chapter=Book V ; Chapter I : History of Don Raphael |orig-year=1748 |accessdate=12 January 2018 }}</ref> ''[[The Fortunes of Nigel]]'' (1822) by [[Walter Scott]] describes [[Malagrowther]], the fictional whipping boy of the young [[James VI of Scotland]] (later also James I of England): "Under the stern rule, indeed, of [[George Buchanan]], who did not approve of the vicarious mode of punishment, James bore the penance of his own faults, and Mungo Malagrowther enjoyed a [[sinecure]]; but James's other pedagogue, Master [[Patrick Young]], went more ceremoniously to work, and appalled the very soul of the youthful King by the floggings which he bestowed on the whipping-boy, when the royal task was not suitably performed."<ref>{{cite book|last=Scott |first=Walter |title=The Fortunes of Nigel |chapterurl=https://www.gutenberg.org/files/5950/old/files/relative.htm#link2HCH0006 |date=25 July 2014 |orig-year=1822 |publisher=Project Gutenberg|chapter=Chapter VI}}</ref> In [[Mark Twain]]'s 1881 novel, ''[[The Prince and the Pauper]]'', the pauper's masquerade as Edward VI is aided by information from the prince's whipping boy,<ref>Bauer & Zirker 2015, ¶41; Twain 2016 [https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1837/1837-h/1837-h.htm#c14 Ch.XIV: 'Le Roi est mort'—'vive le Roi.']</ref> son and namesake of the late Sir Humphrey Marlow, a "Head Lieutenant" in Henry VIII's [[Royal Households of the United Kingdom|Household]].<ref>Bauer & Zirker 2015, ¶41; Twain 2016, * [https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1837/1837-h/1837-h.htm#c29 Ch.XXIX: To London] "'good old Sir Humphrey, Head Lieutenant of the late King’s kitchen, or stables, or something'—Miles could not remember just what or which..." * [https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1837/1837-h/1837-h.htm#c33 Ch.XXXIII: Edward as King.] *:"Know you Sir Humphrey Marlow?" *:The boy started, and said to himself, "Lord! mine old departed father!" </ref> Twain wrote, "James I. and [[Charles II of England|Charles II.]] had whipping-boys, when they were little fellows, to take their punishment for them when they fell short in their lessons; so I have ventured to furnish my small prince with one, for my own purposes."<ref>Bauer & Zirker 2015, ¶41; Twain 2016, [https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1837/1837-h/1837-h.htm#link35-403 Notes: No.8]</ref>
''[[The Whipping Boy]]'' by [[Sid Fleischman]], which won the 1987 [[Newbery Medal]] for children's books, tells of the brattish Prince Horace who learns humility on an adventure with his whipping boy, a rat-catcher named Jemmy.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Whipping Boy|last=Fleischman|first=Sid|publisher=Green Willow Books|year=1986|isbn=0688062164}}</ref> In [[George R. R. Martin]]'s fantasy series ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'', published from 1991, the characters Tommen Baratheon and [[Joffrey Baratheon]] have a whipping boy named Pate.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Feast for Crows|last=Martin|first=George R. R.|publisher=Bantam Spectra|year=2005|isbn=055358202X|location=United States|pages=344–363}}</ref> In [[David Belbin]]'s 2002 children's novel ''Boy King'', Barnaby FitzPatrick is whipped by [[John Cheke]] for teaching Edward VI swear-words; when Edward protests that nobody has whipping boys any more, Cheke says "the Duke of Richmond had one". Cheke relents from giving FitzPatrick the whipping owed to Edward.<ref name="Belbin2013">{{cite book|last=Belbin|first=David|title=Boy King|chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=pBDVBAAAQBAJ&pg=PT28|accessdate=18 January 2018|date=1 October 2013|publisher=Bloomsbury |isbn=9781472904218|pages=28–29|chapter=Whipping Boy}}</ref> [[Sarah Ruhl]]'s 2016 play "Scenes from Court Life, or The Whipping Boy and His Prince" includes whipping boys in its depictions of Charles I and Charles II of England.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://yalecollege.yale.edu/event/theater-scenes-court-life-or-whipping-boy-and-his-prince-sarah-ruhl|title=Theater: Scenes from Court Life or the whipping boy and his prince By Sarah Ruhl|year=2016|work=Calendar|publisher=Yale College|accessdate=9 January 2018}}</ref>

the amusements, eccentricities, accomplishments, superstitions, and frolics of the kings and queens of Europe |chapter=Royalty Whipt and Married by Proxy |pages=306–312 |location=London |publisher=Nimmo }} * {{cite book |last=Twain |first=Mark |title=The Prince and The Pauper |url=https://www.gutenberg.org/files/1837/1837-h/1837-h.htm |date=18 August 2016 |publisher=[[Project Gutenberg]] |orig-year=1882 }} * {{cite book |last=Wesselski |first=Albert |title=Erlesenes |chapter=Der Prügelknabe |publisher=Gesellschaft Deutscher Bücherfreunde in Böhmen |location=Prague |year=1928 |pages=126–128 |language=German}} * {{cite journal |journal=The magazine of art |title=Current Art |pages=133, 170–171 |volume=6 |date=1883 |url=https://archive.org/stream/magazineofart06londuoft#page/171 |accessdate=9 January 2018 }}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} '''Year Nine''' is an educational year group in schools in many countries including the [[United Kingdom]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]. It is the ninth or tenth year of compulsory education.
==Australia== In [[education in Australia|Australia]], Year 9 is usually the tenth year of compulsory education. Although there are slight variations between the states, most children in Year 9 are aged between fourteen and fifteen.<ref name="aus">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mceetya.edu.au/verve/_resources/Volume_1_CSSA_Final_Report.pdf|title=Cost/Benefit Analysis Relating to the Implementation of a Common School Starting Age and Associated Nomenclature by 1 January 2010|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Atelier Learning Solutions Pty Ltd|format=PDF}}</ref>
==New Zealand== In [[education in New Zealand|New Zealand]], Year 9 is the ninth year of compulsory education, and the first year of secondary education. Children entering Year Nine are generally aged between 12.5 and 14.<ref name="NZ">{{Cite web|url=http://www.teamup.co.nz/Child/SchoolEducation/SchoolBasics/SchoolYearsAndLevels.aspx|title=School years and levels|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Ministry of Education|work=Team-up website}}</ref> Year Nine pupils are educated in [[secondary school]]s or [[area school]]s.<ref name="NZ2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.teamup.co.nz/Child/SchoolEducation/SchoolBasics/TypesOfSchools.aspx|title=Types of schools|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Ministry of Education|work=Team-up website}}</ref>
==United Kingdom== In [[education in England|England]] and [[education in Wales|Wales]], Year Nine is the ninth year after [[Reception (school)|Reception]]. It is the ninth full year of compulsory education, with children being admitted who are aged 13 before 1 September in any given academic year.<ref name="sec">{{Cite web|url=http://curriculum.qca.org.uk/key-stages-3-and-4/organising-your-curriculum/the_secondary_curriculum/index.aspx|title=The secondary curriculum|accessdate=2009-01-10|publisher=Qualifications and Curriculum Authority|work=National Curriculum website}}</ref> It is also the year in which pupils are formally assessed against [[National Curriculum assessment|National Curriculum levels]].<ref name="nct">{{Cite web|url=http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Parents/Schoolslearninganddevelopment/ExamsTestsAndTheCurriculum/DG_10013041|title=National Curriculum teacher assessments and key stage tests|accessdate=2009-01-10|work=Directgov website}}</ref> With effect from 2009, National Curriculum Tests are no longer compulsory in this year group.<ref name="ks3nct">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dcsf.gov.uk/pns/DisplayPN.cgi?pn_id=2008_0229|title=Major reforms to school accountability including an end to compulsory national tests for fourteen-year-olds. More support in Year Seven to help children make the jump to secondary school. Ed Balls announces new ‘school report cards’ |accessdate=2009-01-11|publisher=Department for Children, Schools and Families|work=Press Release}}</ref> Year Nine is usually the third year of [[Secondary school]] and was previously known as the 'third year' or 'third form'. Some schools in the UK (especially [[grammar schools]] and [[private schools]]) still refer to 'year 9' as 'third year'. In most schools in England and Wales, it is also the final year of [[Key Stage 3]]. [[Year 9]] pupils are usually aged between 13 and 14 years old. Pupils usually either choose or start their options for their [[GCSE]] qualifications in Year 9.
In [[education in Scotland|Scotland]], Year Nine is the equivalent to [[Second year]] (S2) where pupils start at the age of 12 or 13 and end the at the age of 13 or 14. In Second year pupils pick subjects for [[Third year]].
In [[education in Northern Ireland|Northern Ireland]], Year Nine is the second year of Secondary education. Children in Year 9 are aged between 12 and 13. It is the second year of [[Key Stage 3]].<ref name="NI">{{Cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/SI/si2006/20061915.htm#3|title=The Education (Northern Ireland) Order 2006|accessdate=January 2009}}-</ref>
